Erica is called on to apologize
1413311211222111111112212222211.content:
Madison did not really know what to expect from the academic decathlon team concerning this unexpected, and mainly unwanted attention. Heck, she was actually a bit shocked that Jeff took the attention in the article as well as he did. She thought back to the beginning of the year when they first met, and she was sure that Jeff would have been overcome by anxiety surrounding of someone singling him out for his weight like that. Now, if anything, he seemed to be the one who was re-assuring Madison.

Between the epiphany from Megan, finally letting her Mom know that she had gained weight, her normal coursework and the preparations for the upcoming academic competition, Madison was feeling a bit overwhelmed, and seemed to be eating more to calm herself down. Now, outside of meals with Jeff, she found herself grazing on chips or chocolate, and the sudden satisfaction of food always made her feel a bit more able to tackle what laid ahead for her.

A positive that she never could have expected was the swift reaction against the article, starting with none other than Dr. Crawford. He called Madison a few days later while she was walking down campus,

"Madison, sorry I could not call earlier, it's been a rather busy week."

"Oh, well, that's okay."

"I imagine you read the article in the Proclaimer?"

"Unfortunately, yes"

"Well, I just want to apologize for that, and let you know that I think it's garbage, and that it will have absolutely no effect on how the team is run. I was a bit confused even reading it, because body image and the goals of the team are not any more connected than any other activity."

"I agree."

"Listen, I talked with some other past members of the team, and we wrote a counter which will be in the paper next week, I hope you are okay with that."

"That's fine. Although part of me wishes that we could just move on from this and focus on the competition."

"I hear you." Dr. Crawford said, before mentioning that he had to go.

Madison was a bit nervous about the response op-ed that was sent in. Would that just be another opportunity to highlight how large she currently was? Heck, she did not even consider herself to be obese, and now it would be mentioned in the paper for another week?

As Madison continued throughout the week, she noticed that the mood on campus seemed to be decidedly against Erica's column, something like 70/30 oppose/support. Girls that she hardly, knew, even thinner ones, talked to her and told her how rude they thought it was. Madison could not figure out if people were just being polite, or if they actually thought that. However, one thing remained consistent throughout this, her weight was still creeping up. Madison thought that her clothes were getting a bit tighter, and they were. If she had time to weigh herself, she would see that the constant snacking had brought her up to 189 pounds.
1413311211222111111112212222211.title: Madison and Jeff get support from the team

choices: Erica accepts Keli's invitation
Erica is pressured to stand her ground
14133112112221111111122122222112.content:
Mr. Crawford’s encouragement was welcome, but so was the response from the team. None of the others were as large as Madison and Jeff but most were on the heavier side and none appreciated the slam from Erica, the disgruntled cheerleader.

“OK, I hear you,” responded Madison after allowing an initial 15 minute discussion, “but let’s remember to stay focused. You all have your team assignments and we know what has to be done. Professor Crawford and the Administration are behind us and we have all heard from the student body. Rehashing the obvious ad infinitum here is a distraction.”

The tea got the point and began running thru their role playing drills. After an hour all signs indicated they were well prepared for the expected queries. What they didn’t know was that Madison had another matter on her mind. She had been asked to come to Mrs. Green’s office that afternoon.

Madison showed up wearing a loose floral print jacket which cut off just below her waist atop a solid color one piece black dress that came down to her knees. The effect was to give her a professional rather than routine student persona, one that said “I mean business.”

The imaging was intentional, suggested by Jeff, and designed to illustrate Madison was unbowed, ready to play offense and not defense. She seated herself confidently in the waiting room outside Ms Green’s office, tugging slightly on her hemline due to its snugness. After less than five minutes she was invited into the office precisely on time. She was surprised to find there a large, friendly appearing middle-aged woman who was introduced as Gwendolyn Porter.

“Mrs. Porter is an Alumnus of Powers and Chairperson of the Alumni Association’s UMILA outreach effort,” stated Mrs. Green. “She wanted to meet you personally.”

“Well, thank you,” said Madison. “I hope you’ll pardon me for not knowing much about UMILA – what is it?”

“The Upward Mobility Initiative for Larger Alumni,” Mrs Porter answered.” “We’re preparing a firestorm to singe the feathers of this Erica twit who dared to attack you in the Proclaimer. Youi deserve an apology my dear and she needs to be taken down somewhat.”

“Well that’s truly kind of you,” answered Madison, “but the last time I looked the first amendment encompasses the right to say stupid things. Forcing her into a retraction against her will, as the saying goes, would leave her of the same opinion still. But I appreciate your thought and support.”

Mrs. Porter turned to Mrs Green. “Is she saying she won’t come to the rally we’re staging later this week?”

“I doubt if she has even heard about it,” answered Mrs green “Madison has classes and is coaching a team plus acting as a private coach under assignment from my office. She didn’t even know about the article till a dormitory mate called it to her attention.”

“I see,” paused Mrs Porter. “Well, about a dozen of us will be circulating petitions at the dining hall beginning in two days demanding an apology on your behalf or else suspension for this Erica. We would appreciate your presence and a few words as to how much this has hurt and angered you”

Madison blinked her eyes and rolled her eyeballs at Mrs Porters assumptions and proposal. It was totally opposite of the response she ad Jeff were encouraging.

“Now hold on,” Madision countered. “What Erica did was totally boorish and obviously bigoted, but making demands like that will only focus attention on her remarks and possibly turn her into a martyr. I think a rally in support of our team without even mentioning the Proclaimer or her would be far more constructive.”

“With all the fatophobic nonsense going on today you can be that sanguine?” sputtered Mrs Porter. “Surely you’re not ignorant of the barriers people of our size face?”

“Maybe not as much as you, but I want to be rewarded for my own efforts and talent, not made a poster child for victimization,” fired back Madison. “I was telling the team just today that we need to avoid being distracted and focus on what we need to be doing to win. It is important as Captain that I follow my own advice. I would personally appreciate your supporting us as a team rather than making a possible martyr out of Erica. And, no, neither Jeff or I will be a part of any protest rally. Is there anything else to discuss?”

“I guess so, Madison. Thanks for taking time to come by,” interjected Mrs Green.

Madison smiled graciously and left. As she went down the hall she overheard Mrs Green saying to Mrs Porter “I told you she wouldn’t go for it.”

As soon as she was out of the building Madison hurriedly called Jeff, asking him to have his mother use her influence to temper the alumni zealots. She wondered whether she should try contacting contact Erica personally, but decided against it.

Getting back to the dorm she was hoping to talk with her friends, but none were home. Cassie apparently had been – a box from Dunkin Donuts was in the kitchen with two items gone.

“This kind of comfort food grazing is what makes people like Erica go berserk,” Madison thought. She was tempted to grab a strawberry Danish for herself, but resisted, electing to go to her room and pull off her jacket and dress. With the jacket’s padded shoulders and contrasting cutoff she felt she’d looked good, but noted the dress was also a tad snug. With her dress off her burgeoning belly spread out as she sat down half-clad at her computer, tying to focus on work for the team.

A half hour after she heard someone come in and hastily covered up. She came the living room as Kelly was moving the pastry box onto the coffee table to share with Cassie, who was bringing in milk from the kitchen.

“Hey there," Kelly said, ”if isn’t the talk of the campus! I think everyone is planning on attending the competition to see you squash the competition and belie Erica’s accusations.”

“You said it,” concurred Cassie. “I’d not mind giving her a few comeuppences myself.”

“Whoa, you two,” replied Madison.”Tell me, does she have a life besides her team? Any boyfriends, hobbies, etc? From what I can tell she’s a poor girl who lives at home with her parents and hasn’t a clue. All she’s doing is parroting talking points she’s picked up from somewhere to get attention.”

“Surprising statement, but I think you may be right. I never heard of her until two days ago,” responded Kelli as she began devouring the strawberry Danish Madison had been contemplating earlier. “I wouldn’t know her if I saw her, and I’m fairly sociable.”

“I think we share a class,” Cassie commented, “but nothing notable there. She hasn’t raised her hand once that I remember, nor have I seen her being friends with anyone. I can’t help but wonder if someone put her up to writing that letter. She doesn’t seem the contentious type.”

“Maybe we should get to know her?” suggested Kelly.

“After what she did to Madison?” responded Cassie

“Actually yes – especially because of that,” Madison interjected. “If I thought she’d accept it and I had the time I might do it myself. But don’t take her any pastry boxes if you expect to succeed.”

Both dorm mates laughed, unaware of the discussion Jeff at that moment was having long distance with his Mom.

         “Gwen Porter means well, I’m sure, but Madison feels that what she wants to do is totally counter-productive. I agree. Why can’t the alumni support the team instead of drawing attention to another fatophobe?”

         “I have to say you’re probably right,” Mrs Wilson agreed. :”I’ll see what I can do.”

Meanwhile Erica herself was reeling from the blowback her article had generated. Some students agreed with her, but most did not. Some were getting downright mean – slipping pictures of an anorexia victim into one of her textbooks with the her name and the caption “Future Power’s Team Captain Candidate?” But what was really bothersome were the glares, glances and fingerpointing. She could only wonder why she’d agreed to take the dare of writing the letter just to see if the college paper would publish it. She never dreamed they would. Erica had come home shaking with the pressure she was feeling. She was surprised to check her email later that night and find a message from Kelli with the subject line “In defense of Madison Kraft,”

“Dear Erica:

I respect your right, and that of every Power’s student, to make whatever decisions you choose for yourself as long as they affect principally you.

But when they affect the reputation of someone I know well and you’ve never even talked to I must speak out.

Madison Kraft isn’t Captain because of Jeff Wilson. She is Captain, and his girlfriend, because she has been a proactive person – both in class and in helping him as a personal trainer. She has been involved successfully with this type of team before and was recruited to come to Powers because of it – something you likely didn’t know but the alumni association faculty did before she ever knew the Wilsons.

Is she a big person? Yes, but in more ways than one. She at this moment is doing her best to head off a protest rally directed at you personally. Bet you didn’t know that either.

I doubt if you even know who I am, and I don’t pretend to know what makes you so loathe your fatter classmates (yes, that includes me). But if you would like to talk at lunch tomorrow (I know you don’t usually eat at the dining hall) I’ll spring for the meal. I think someone needs to throw you a life preserver – if you want one. Interestingly Madison would be willing to give me a hand if you decide to grab it. Rather than being angry she feels sorry for you!

Kelli (dorm mate and friend of Madison)”
Erica stared at the screen. A life preserver? Well, she did feel like she was drowning. But who was this Kelli and could she be trusted? How should she respond?
14133112112221111111122122222112.title: Erica is called on to apologize

choices: They talk for a while
Erica is judgemental
141331121122211111111221222221121.content:
Erica did not know what to do as she starred at the open email, having moved from reading the text to know just starring through the screen, trying to process her options. Why would Kelli reach out to her like that? Plus, would she really want to accept?

Erica had been popular in high school, very popular, and part of that could be attributed to her perfect looks. Besides her great face, she had the same flawless body that she currently possessed and she was fine using it to her advantage. However, when she got to college, Erica did not have the instant friend surge that she expected, much to the contrast of Madison's experience. Erica wasn't having the same entourage of social contacts, or parade of guys who were interested in her like she was used to in high school.

She could not put her finger on why this happened. Had she come to college with expectations that were too high? Had her previous popularity and social clique erode her abilities to make new friends? Did going to a school in her hometown and live with her parents rob her of bonding experiences? Was she too intimidating for the slightly larger classmates? She assumed it was a combination of all these things, but one thing was certain, she was not pleased with the status quo for herself at Powers.

Maybe that's why she wrote the letter she now greatly resisted in the first place. Her initial thoughts were that this would be something that would get people talking. And they were, but not to her liking, if anything, she feared that she was making herself a social outcast with that.

All of these thoughts were riffling through her head as she tried to figure out what to do about the email.

After a while, Erica decided that she should take Kelli up on the invitation. Although in the email, Kelli had claimed that it was possible Erica never noticed her, that was not the case, as she had recognized her after seeing her talk with Cassie, the larger girl who she shared a class with. Although she was afriad this would be a chance for Kelli to subject her to biting criticism, she decided that it was worth attending.

When Erica got to the cafeteria, she walking in an saw a taller girl sitting alone, clearly waiting for someone. I think that's her... Erica thought as she walked up to the girl who was wearing her high school basketball sweatpants, which seemed a bit snug.
141331121122211111111221222221121.title: Erica accepts Keli's invitation

choices: The protest turns into a support rally
Not everyone is as sanguine as Kelli and Madison
1413311211222111111112212222211211.content:
Kelli had spotted Erica looking around somewhat apprehensively. The Powers dining hall with its cornucopia of entrees and desserts was not the cheerleader’s normal turf. Living at home and bringing her sparse lunches to school each day insured that she wouldn't be a regular. As she looked around at the heavier patrons with their jovial smiles and full food trays it struck Erica that this was a different culture. But she was looking for Kelli, who had promised via reply email to be on hand.

As Erica tentatively approached the table where Kelli was waiting the 5’ 10 freshman rose, the 25 pounds she’d gained since August thinly disguised by the exercise suit. Kelli had better items in her wardrobe but was dressing down deliberately to put Erica at ease. As Erica approached she smiled and greeted her with as much warmth as she could muster, “Hey, I’m glad you made it! Let’s grab some trays and remember, I’m buying so have what you want,”

Erica swallowed. She was expecting hostility but was instead being offered hospitality. She turned towards the serving line, grabbed a tray and soon selected a tuna salad which included sliced hard boiled eggs, greens, olives and miniature tomatoes. Kelli followed her lead. When they reached the cashier Kelli used her card and paid cash for Erica.

As the two students made their way to an empty table Erica braced for an interrogation and lecture, but Kelli ignored the article and simmering controversy. Instead she asked Erica about herself, then shared parallel areas in her own background. Finally Erica couldn’t help but blurt out, “why all this discussion about us – aren’t we here to discuss what I did?”

“We are, actually. But not I hope confrontationally,“ smiled Kelli. “We barely know one another. I’m trying to understand what makes you tick and am sharing with you what I understand of myself for the same reason. Actions don’t just happen in a vacuum – there’s context for everything. I know what you wrote – I want to understand why you felt the need to do it,”

“My sister Ellie and I had a discussion. She thinks this is a school for stuck-up fatties who think they’re special – she bet me that if I wrote something like that it would prove her point, then our parents would let me go somewhere else. She doesn’t want to come here at all,” related Erica, “I know I probably shouldn’t have singled Madison out, but you’re right – I don’t understand this place.”

“Ummm, I see,” mused Kelli. “So in a sense she put you up to the letter. That helps me understand the event, but what about you. Do you feel pressure from anyone here at Powers to be bigger? Because if you are, then someone is delivering a wrong message.”

“Not pressure really, just a lack of inclusion. You are the first person to invite me to anything – and its only because I crossed a line,” asserted Erica.

Kelli closed her eyes and bowed her head, then murmured :”at one level I know you’re right. Those of us who live in dorms generally don’t reach out to those living off campus. Maybe we should. If we had a potluck for people like you how many do you think you could get to come?”

“I don’t’ know – but its not just association. Its philosophy. We have an obesity epidemic and people here treat it like its another hoax like global warming or affordable health care. I don’t enjoy depriving myself of food, but its essential for both health and acceptance.” declared Erica,.

“Perhaps for you that is reality, and like I wrote in my email, that's your right. I have to respect your right to live your life according to your beliefs. But its not the only reality out there. There are those who either enjoy being larger or can’t maintain a low weight and feel right. Don’t they have the right to come to another conclusion?”countered Kelli “That’s where the blowback you’re getting is coming from – no one saying you need to become heavier to be accepted. We just want acceptance of our choices as well.”

“You don’t think being heavier is bad? It should just be accepted like hair or skin color?” Erica remarked in astonishment.

“Every choice has pluses and minuses, but we should make them for ourselves. Being too lean carries risks just like being heavier – and being really too skinny or really too fat can create issues, but why do we judge others rather than just ourselves in either case? That’s my question to you.” replied Kelli, bringing the point home.

“Well, I feel forced into my choice, so I guess I want to do the same to others perhaps?” answered Erica a little tentatively.

“Probably true,” Kelli answered. “I have four heavier dorm mates, each larger for a different reason. But I get along with all of them because I let them live their own lives. But society tries to shoehorn us from every side – just like it has you. Even elementary school kids are protesting the food in the school lunch programs and are posting picture on Facebook. Its your life, Erica. You need to live it the way you choose and let others do likewise. Does that make sense?”

“Actually, yes." Erica conceded “Will you tell Madison I’m sorry and will write a retraction to the Proclaimer?”

“That’s good and I will. But I think it would be more meaningful if you joined us for a meal and said that,” suggested Kelli.

“She’d do that?” Erica said shaking her head.

“Yes,” replied Kelli, “We have one slated for Monday night. Don’t feel that you need to eat anymore than you feel like just because others are digging in.” .

“I understand, and thank you,” the humbled cheerleader replied.

After lunch Kelli called Madison on her cell and told her the outcome.

“Great,” exclaimed Madison. “Now let’s hope Jeff is as successful in heading off tomorrow’s protest.”
1413311211222111111112212222211211.title: They talk for a while

choices: The Monday Evening Dinner
Something else befre Monday
14133112112221111111122122222112111.content:
When Erica arrived home Emily immediately inquired as to the discussion with Kelli.

“It went well, actually. Kelli was reaching out trying to understand my thinking and trying to share her views. I liked her. Madison told her to invite me to a dormitory dinner – they’re trying to build bridges. I’m going to apologize in the paper and maybe go to dinner with them on Monday. I’m sorry, but I think you persuaded me to jump the gun,” Erica replied to her sister.

Emily fumed. “You’re selling out to the establishment! Next thing you know these porkers will have you stuffing your face with candy and joining them. You know the agenda I’ve embraced – meaningful change means exploiting ever opportunity for division to tear out the old order, not finding common ground. You need to read Alinsky’s Rules for Radicals!”

Erica stood her ground. “You’re the social justice revolutionary not me! Just because Michelle wants to declare war on fat doesn’t make all fat people my enemy or that I should hold them back. Did it ever occur to you that maybe they’re fat for a reason – may even want to be in some cases? As long as they don’t insist that I be like them to be accepted isn’t that OK? Isn’t this a free country?”

Emily shook her head in disdain, “so now you’re alright with making fatties your friend just because one accepts you when you expected a fight. I tell you fatties are inferior and weak people who need to be receivers of entitlement class, not the intelligentsia. No wonder the occupy movement demonstrations go nowhere with your kind of thinking.”

“Actually demonstrations can go both ways, answered Erica.”Madison’s boyfriend is trying to head off a pro-fat demonstration that my letter triggered. It was meant to change the decision, but instead most on campus are supporting Madison’s team. I’m not wanting to be on the losing side just to further a revolutionary agenda.”

Emily shook her head, “Ok, go get stuffed on Monday. Gain a hundred pounds if you like. You’ve probably just handed Powers the State championship and then fatties everywhere will think they are as good as anyone and don’t need protection. No wonder America is so backward.”

With that Emily left the room, leaving Erica to her thoughts. Meanwhile Jeff was making progress with UMILA and Gwendolyn Porter.

“Our team is capable of winning the championship hands down,” Jeff was arguing. “But having a distraction over this stupid bigoted letter could sidetrack us. I fully get your anger and frustration, I really do, but Madison is our captain and she sees something as well.

“Which is?”

Jeff inhaled. “She feels that since we have the support of Professor Crawford and the administration having a demonstration over size detracts from what we’re going into this contest to prove that we are #1 in Kansas “

Gwendolyn was an angry fat woman, but she wasn’t stupid. She sat thinking as Jeff paused to assess her reaction before continuing. “We’ve all seen what this Sterling jerk’s comments did to morale on the Clippers team – we frankly don’t need it here. Jackie Robinson let his playing skills speak for him in the forties – please, give us a shot at doing this the same way. ”

Tears welled up in the UNILA leader’s eyes, her arm shook and her voice trembled. “I want to put trollops like her their place so bad. Even though your family has supported us with money and you’re big yourself you can’t know the pain boiling inside those who’ve lived with remarks and insults all our lives, but I know you have a point. You deserve the chance to win because you’re simply the best – and that means focusing without us demonstrating. I understand,”

Jeff’s cell phone vibrated. It was a text from Madison. “K sez E to apologize in Proclaimer; has been invited Mon nite dinner. Hope she accepts”

Jeff smiled and showed the message to Gwendolyn. “I suggest you show up tomorrow with signs supporting the team – ignore the letter because its about to become history.”

The UMILA President looked at Jeff. “That girl is something else – more charitable than I’d be. But then, she didn’t grow up fat did she?”

“No,“ answered Jeff, “but she has a fatphobic mom to deal with. Neither of us knows how Mrs Kraft will react when she finds out about us and how big Maddie has become. Interestingly, Maddie has decided being bigger is erotic and is ready to tell her mom to take a hike if she gives her grief.”

“Pluck and courage! You hold on to that one, Jeff,” Mrs Porter smiled and counseled.

“I intend to,” replied Jeff.

The next day Kelli and Erica stood on the sidelines of the dining hall plaza as local news media photographed a pep rally in support of the Powers team. UMILA members who had invited them to come had placards of support rather than protest as Professor Crawford outlined what the tournament was all about; Madison then introduced the event teams. They the conducted a mock competition for ten minutes, then encouraged all present to attend the official event.

“This is no different than in regular sports,” remarked Erica, “a team representing the school and everyone spurring them on.”

“Exactly,” replied Kelli. “Madison has confirmed the invitation for Monday and Jeff says he would like to meet you as well. Are we on?’

“Yes,” answered Erica. “And last night I wrote the letter – although my sister thinks I’m nuts. To her I’ve sold out to the enemy and betrayed the President’s wife. She doesn’t get what I think you’ve been trying to tell me.”

“Elites always think that they know what’s best for everyone else. Its that attitude, not their money or education or position, that makes them elitists. In some cases they may even be logically right in their opinions. But not everyone can embrace everyone else’s concept of right and that’s why we are different. We need to leave life choices in many areas up to those who must live with them,” answered Kelli. “If were simply a matter of choosing a number when it comes to weight it would be one thing – but there are so many other factors involved.”

The two new friends parted, looking forward to Monday night. Erica pondered Kelli’s words, wondering if Madison’s emissary sensed her deeper thoughts. And how would Emily react if she even suspected? Erica couldn’t see herself becoming fat but was aware her emotions on the issue as it applied to others shifting.
14133112112221111111122122222112111.title: The protest turns into a support rally

choices: The dinner progresses
The following week
141331121122211111111221222221121111.content:
As Monday night rolled around, Erica was nervous. She had never actually confronted Madison and Jeff, or even seen them, since the Proclaimer article. Sure, Kelli was acting as an emissary of sorts between the groups, but Erica still had no way to know if she was in for an awkward dinner, or if they actually were planning on on making nice with her.

While she was getting ready, Emily was still having none of the idea.

"You're putting on your trendy jeans? Better enjoy them while you still can!" Emily said with a laugh.

"What does that mean?" Erica asked, knowing full well.

"You were the ones that showed me photos of Madison. You said it best yourself, once that group seems to take a hold of someone, they tend to gain weight." Emily said, acting as if she had a surefire theory.

"That was a while ago."

"Half a week is not a while ago, Erica." Emily said.

"I can be reserved and be friends with them," Erica protested, "plus, who knows if I'll ever see these people again, I just need to clear the air with them so this thing, that you pushed me to do, by the way, goes away. This past week has been horrible, and they are being nice enough to try to stop it. The least I can do is join them for dinner."


On the other side of campus, Madison was equally nervous. Starring at her closet in her underwear, she wondered what to pick out. These are the times I wish I were still thin. Madison thought to herself, Then I would have a world of clothes to choose from. My clothes. Not these stand ins. Madison was almost borderline cranky with the idea of the dinner, in stark contrast to where she was when the idea was a bit further out. But now, the idea of meeting thin as a rail Erica, while she was huge, over weight issues was another step in the long journey of her weight acceptance. During the weekend, Madison snacked more, and her weight had climbed up to 194 pounds. Not only did that mean she was feeling temporarily uncomfortable about her current appearance, it also meant that she faced the more practical issue of an ill fitting wardrobe. As she tried on the last remaining pair of jeans, Madison sucked in her gut, and barley got the jeans fastened. It left a muffin top, that Madison tried to conceal with a loose fitting top. However, there was no escaping that her arms looked softer and her chin puffier.


When the dinner finally got underway, Kelli started off trying to bridge the conversation topics between them. It was a slow and hard task, given the mutual awkwardness between them, and Jeff's natural shyness. Not helping were their socio-economic differences. Madison was the formerly hot, still rich and urban girl from a huge city. Erica's background was decidedly more blue collar, and Madison was almost having feelings of superiority and insecurity at the same time, a very odd sensation.

Finally, Kelli got to the topic of working out. "Erica, I'm surprised that you have not seen Madison at the gym, her and Jeff work out together." Erica was shocked that Madison was a workout buddy to anyone, given her size.

"You're still working out?" Erica asked, trying to be polite.

"Yeah," Madison said, "Jeff and I met because we were in a class together and I was the instructor," trying not to embarrass Jeff, Madison side stepped the point of the class, "It was about healthy lifestyle. As you can see," Madison said, patting her belly, "perhaps I could pay better attention."

"No, you've been a great teacher," Jeff pipped in. "I've lost around 45 pounds since I started. Madison has been a great teacher."

Kelli noticed that Jeff was eating a lot less than everyone at the table, heck, even than her. Maybe this group was more deep than she had assumed, and the weight issue multi-dimensional.
141331121122211111111221222221121111.title: The Monday Evening Dinner

choices: Erica and Emily have a falling out
The state competition beckons
1413311211222111111112212222211211111.content:
Erica estimated that her four dinner companions collectively weighed over a thousand pounds, with Jeff being the largest followed by Cassie and then Madison. Kelli was obviously the smallest but still outweighing Erica by probably sixty pounds. Cassie had prepared salad, a casserole, and two vegetable sides – all served family style in a semi-formal setting with cloth napkins and silverware.

She found the meal, to be satisfying – certainly higher calorie fare than she was used to, but she wasn’t about to make that the focus of the evening. She was intrigued by the fact that Cassie and Kelli both alluded to boyfriends on the Powers campus, but she bypassed that topic. She wanted to steer the conversation into why she knew she was there, so she addressed her remarks to Cassie, who seemed to be functioning as hostess

“Cassie,” Erica began, “I’m here at Powers for a different reason than maybe most – it was what my parents could afford that wasn’t a state run school. But you seem to be here by choice. Can I ask how that happened?

“Well, our family tends to be heavier, although its never been a source of major health issues, probably because we’re physically active and don’t eat a lot of process4ed foods. Ours is a corn-fed community with most folk on the chunky side, so its never been a peer group pressure issue. But when you get into mainstream America the “thin is it” mantra can affect you – which is why my aunt, who used to be a thin city girl, thought Powers would be a great place for me,” explained Cassie. “I was able to get a scholarship so I came.”

“You Aunt came to Powers herself?” Erica responded

“No, she wasn’t heavier until later in life. She went to the University of Illinois and weight issues I doubt crossed her mind, She gradually became bigger after getting married to my Uncle, who works in Kansas City. But after getting used to the idea and accepting it she found out about Powers and wished it had been her school. She’s over 200 now, but was probably eighty pounds less when she and Uncle Phil got married. Its kind of cute what happened.”

“How do you mean?” Erica probed.

“Phil was bigger than her,” Cassie continued, ”A little husky, and he’d picked up a few pounds when they went to a holiday dinner about six months after they were married. He got teased a little about his paunch and Betsy decided to help him by making sure there was less for him to eat at their house. That meant she had to eat deliberately what he instead might.”

Erica paused. “How did that work?”

“If Phil brought home snack foods like mini-donuts for a snack he used to consume two thirds of them and give her a couple,” Cassie explained. Now she’d make sure to have at least half. If there were leftovers at supper she’d have seconds so he couldn’t raid the refrigerator. She figured hat by eating more herself so there would be less for him. She thought she could do that without gaining very much, if anything, because she never had a weight gain problem.”

“It didn’t work I’m guessing.” Erica remarked

“Well, it partially did,” Cassie remarked. “As the months passed he lost the new chub but she picked up some. She got a little spare tire muffin top – which she regarded as minor. But her family picked up on it the next holiday get together. They needled her, saying it wasn’t just 5-6 pounds like she was estimating, making odds on whether it was 10 pounds or more. Finally she got on a scale and was surprised to find out she’d gained 17 pounds. She was shocked, but my Uncle protested that she looked better for it and that was that. A diet she’d thought about never happened, but the next year brought ten more pounds. Two kids and five years later it was another fifty.”

“And she and her husband are both OK with that?” Erica marveled

“Erica, strange as it may seem to you, yes. Phil makes no secret of how much he likes it. After getting to know our family I think she adapted, because she’s not shy about filling up her plate when we get together. I’m way heavier than her, as you probably realize, but I think she’s made the transition. Otherwise why would she steer me here or even know about it?”

“That’s a key word – transition,” observed Madison. “When I first noticed my clothes getting tighter the first thing I focused on was what other people, my mom I particular, would notice – not about how I felt about it. Becoming larger happens – accepting it in today’s environment has to be a conscious effort. And having your Uncle Phil in her corner had to have been a factor.”

“Definitely,” Cassie agreed. “There is a concept that all fat folk do is stuff their face with snack foods and sugary pastries, then lounge around. Maybe some do, but I know my weight is from good home style cooking and part of my culture.”

“Powers is reflective of a culture that’s not that traditional by elitist standards,” chimed in Kelli, “but is actually more reflective of how we as a society are. I’m glad to be here.”

“And because I was forced to I’m having a hard time getting it,” Erica mused.

“Could be,” Jeff interjected. “I was practically fattened by my family because of my Mom’s determination not to have a fat-hating son. I’m a bit of a savant and nerd who was off in his own reality and let her do it. Finally, over time, I came to understand that I needed to assert my own independence. Thankfully my Dad, who personally likes larger women in principle, understands. He underwrote the hiring of Madison to help get me to a middle point that will make me effective in business. . What no one expected was that in helping free me she’d find freedom as well. If I can be around 250 I should be fine with my size – and I’m fine with Maddie as well. What we both agree on is that our size s our choice, not our parents or peers.”

“So actually neither of you started out here to be the size you are now?” Erica inquired.

“Nope,” replied Madison. “I was looking to make some side money to be independent, Jeff was trying to break loose from his mom’s dominance and be his own person. But then we really got to know one another as persons. Meanwhile Jeff’s gotten smaller and I’ve gotten bigger. That’s the story.”

“And you have the same choice, Erica,” Kelli said. “The point is, if others choose to be different, larger or smaller, its not easy. And it isn’t right to make fun of anyone.”

“I hope you can forgive me,” she replied.

“Done last week already,“ Madison answered with a smile. “And by the way, thanks for the letter – it will be published this week.”

“Ummm, can I say the meal was great and the advice wise, but I’m wondering if there’s a dessert” Erica asked.

“Apple pie a la mode, and I’ll get right on it” Cassie answered. Erica marveled at the agility of her obviously 200+ body.

Erica left the dorm stuffed but content. She was not planning to give up her own lifestyle, but she had acquired a decidedly different point of view regarding people of size – one she knew Emily wouldn't like.
1413311211222111111112212222211211111.title: The dinner progresses

choices: Madison gains weight preparing for the competition
Erica's lifestyle changes
14133112112221111111122122222112111111.content:
Erica had hoped that Emily would be out with her friends like on a typical evening so she could sneak into her bedroom without seeing her thin-obsessed sister and the certain shakedown that she knew would come. Unfortunately for Erica, Emily was home, having recently got back from a run. Emily was dressed in her tight workout clothes and her hair in a sporty ponytail. She had heard Erica come in, and started the barrage from the couch while watching TV, without looking back at Erica.

"So, how was the farm?" Emily sarcastically asked.

"It went well, they were really nice." Erica responded.

At this point Emily had gotten up to talk with her, and saw the sight of her sister, still in extremely good shape, but with a bit of a bulge in her shirt, where he stomach was sticking out slightly, a sign that she was stuffed. "Wow, I guess it went well," Emily said, giving Erica a slight tap on her stomach, causing the overly full Erica to groan slightly.

"If you don't stop, you're going to end up like them too." Emily said.

"Please stop it," Erica protested, "they're less shallow than us, and they seem happier. If they are fine with their bodies, why should we care?" Erica asked.

"Well aren't you their cheerleader, you're going to end up just as fat as Madison soon!"

That caused Erica to nearly snap. She was tired of her sister being such a prick about this evening. "You know what, at least they have come to terms with their bodies," Erica said, getting more pointed, "And some even know how to control their acne."

Erica knew that was an attack that would harm Emily more than most. Emily had always struggled with acne, having periodic breakouts that crushed her confidence, and made her normal swagger go away.

"Go to hell Erica!" she said, getting up to go towards her room.

"Yeah, it isn't so fun when someone starts making fun of your body, is it?" Erica screamed.

"I'm going to love seeing you get huge, just like those pigs you ate with tonight." Emily snarked as she slammed her bedroom door.

Erica wasn't as angry as Emily was. She just needed to decompress. Grab a quick snack, and watch TV, while she tried to assess what had happened that night. Why does she think I'm going to get fat. Erica thought, That will never happen.
14133112112221111111122122222112111111.title: Erica and Emily have a falling out

choices: Gary and Erica become closer as her appetite improves
Emily continues to harass Erica
141331121122211111111221222221121111112.content:
Erica, her belly, still full from the dinner, fell asleep easily despite the upset of the quarrel with her fat phobic sister. In her dreams the fight continued, but she saw herself as a rational human being arguing with a marionette. The marionette looked like her sister, with strings being pulled by the social justice crowd and chief fatophobe Michelle as the puppeteer.

Erica tossed to and fro, arguing with the puppet. No rational discussion was possible it seemed and gradually she resigned herself to that reality. The dream ended and another one replaced it.

Now, instead of being lectured to by her sister and friends she was at a party. All the girls were larger than her, but had attentive guys and were enjoying themselves. The atmosphere was like the dinner earlier that evening: good food, good fellowship and a feeling of family. It was peaceful and seemed right – except that she was alone. Inwardly, despite that drawback, she relaxed, her nagging sister no longer a presence, and Erica slept soundly for the rest of the night.

By morning Erica’s distended belly was back to normal size but her freshly stretched but now empty stomach was hungry.
Cautiously she rose. Emily was nowhere to be seen. Erica knew she wanted more than her usual cold cereal and a banana for breakfast. She thought of her new friends, probably in the Power’s cafeteria enjoying pancakes, omelets and sausages. Frankly the thought appealed to her as well

Emily’s warning echoed in her ears – if she started eating more she would gain weight. But was that the end of the world? The fat girls at Powers like Cassie and Madison had boyfriends. What did she, Erica, have at the moment?


“Screw it,” Erica declared to herself. “I have a few dollars – so what if I’m not on a Power’s meal plan? One large breakfast isn’t going to make me a blimp – and who knows, I might meet someone if I were a little more available.”

Upon arriving at the dining hall the first thing that caught her eye was a poster proclaiming the Tuesday special of the day – a luscious spicy Mexican breakfast casserole. She could see from the blown up picture that it had eggs, potatoes, beans and black peppers – probably cheese and sour cream as well.

“Well, that’s definitely not low calorie – but it looks tempting,” she thought. “for $3.50 served buffet style I wonder what’s included?’

“Can I help you,” inquired an attendant.

“Yes,” replied Erica, “I don’t usually buy breakfast here but I will be this morning. I was looking at that casserole. What does it come with?”

“Two tortillas, plus guacamole and salsa if you want,” replied the attendant. “You can get coffee with unlimited refills for $1.49.”

Erica saw various other dishes, including corned beef hash, omelets, pancakes, and scrambled eggs, but opted for the casserole. The cafeteria seemed to be becoming quite crowded but she was able to get a small two seat table to herself. About half wayinto her meal another student she recognized from classes seemed at a loss to find a place, standing awkwardly with his tray.

“You’re welcome to join me,” she offered politely.

“Why, ah, thanks,” he replied, taking the opposite seat. “My name is Gary …. and you are?”

“Erica. I think we have third period together. You seemed to need some help,” she replied.

“Yes, got here later than usual and it does fill up. I’ve not seen you here before.”

“No, I usually eat at home, but today I was in a hurry. This casserole certainly eats anything I have time to prepare. I see you chose corn beef hash and eggs – and is that a huge blueberry muffin?’

“Yep- it is pretty big - I could share it with you if you like. By the way, I notice your coffee cup is nearly empty. Could I fill I for you?” he offered.

“Sure – cream and sweet and low, please.” Erica replied. “Let me think about the muffin”

By the time Gary returned Erica had cut the muffin in half and Gary smiled. She was anything but plump but obviously wasn't shy about indulging her appetite. He began wondering whether she’d accept a date.
141331121122211111111221222221121111112.title: Erica's lifestyle changes

choices: Erica hears from her Cheerleading team captain
Gary and Erica draw closer
1413311211222111111112212222211211111122.content:
With her decidedly larger than normal breakfast being digested Erica while in class was glad she hadn’t packed her usual lunch. She still felt full as the noon hour approached and was fretting. She knew the Proclaimer would be coming out the next day and that Gary would likely read it. She wondered if he would make the connection and call off their date. She hoped he didn’t – he seemed like a nice guy and it was the first invitation she’d had from anyone since school started.

She knew how Emily would react. She hated Powers and had put her up to composing her protest piece. Dating a guy who attended there was going to freak her out – especially if food was involved. She wanted to talk to someone – perhaps her mom, but could she be trusted to understand?
Erica arrived home early. None of the rest of the family was there. Shortly after five she heard her mom come home from work. Erica joined her in the kitchen.

“Mom – we need to talk. I have good news and bad news,” she blurted out.

“Oh?” replied a startled Claudia Mays, not used to Erica taking her into her confidence. This had to be serious.

“I have a date for Saturday night, but I don’t know what Emily is going to say. Irs a guy from Powers and he’s taking me to dinner,” Erica explained.

“Swell, that sounds wonderful. I’ve been thinking that college has been so serious for you – you haven’t been that social. But why should Emily care? She’s a high school senior’

“Because its food mother – and Emily thinks enjoying it is wrong. You know how she is – or haven’t you noticed?” Erica said with exasperation.

“You’re over 18 – if the young man treats you well and you enjoy his company, why should your sister’s feelings about food control you? Neither of us can control her!” responded her mom. “Maybe you need to be your own person more.”

“Really? You’re honestly not afraid I could gain a few pounds She thinks so. Personally I don’t think I’m anywhere near needing to worry about such things, but for the last three years she’s been a nag.” Erica answered. “In fact, I’m sorry for asking you going along with her. Grape-nuts, bananas and toast aren’t really much of a breakfast.”

“Emily does I guess overdo it, sweetheart. Maybe I should prepare dessert for a change tonight just to make a point,” Mrs. Mays suggested. “Your father has complained about the focus on rabbit food as well. But I thought it was what you and your sister both wanted.”

“I know. I’ve gone along, but enough is enough. Can I help you with making that dessert,” Erica volunteered.

“Surely, and I can also make sure other things are available for breakfast meals if you’ll use them. Pre-prepared crepes and pre-made won ton wrappers are great for a variety of things – I could put some in the freezer if you want to experiment.

“Hmmm, go ahead. *I can see the potential,” replied Erica thoughtfully as she strapped on an apron.

Emily’s discomfiture was obvious that evening as Mrs. Mays served the family beef stroganoff with green beans pus Erica’s apple crisp for dessert. Erica served herself generous portions and Mr. Mays commended his wife for the surprise change in menu. Emily glared at her sister but held her peace as Erica just smiled.
After supper Emily cornered Erica and demanded to know what was going on.

“Simple, dear sister. I’ve gone over to the other side – not to be a fatty but not be a fanatic either. And, oh yes, I have a dinner date on Saturday,” she disclosed cheerily.

“And tomorrow morning you’re having cheese blintzes for breakfast I suppose,” her sister retorted.

“Ummm, don’t think we have the fixings. But Mom did talk about getting some pre-frozen crepes and wontons to put in the freezer so that I could experiment with menu variety,” Erica said coolly.

“You cooking? When did this start?” answered Emily.

“Actually with dessert tonight. But don’t you remember that I got an A in Home Ec? I can do it when I want –but you’ve made me feel guilty and that’s stopping.” Erica declared.

“You know what Miss Stennis has warned about … start eating a little and it’s a slippery slope. Next thing you know you’re a butterball,” Emily parried.

“She’s been preaching that line for years and probably believes it. But have you considered that its that attitude that’s made her an old maid? She’s even admitted she doesn’t want a husband and family. I don’t know why she is a teacher.”.” Erica declared.

“You just don’t understand about inequality and social injustice – she’s given up traditional values to try to change things,” Emily asserted.

“And that’s her right, although I’m starting to wonder if it belongs in school. But others have right to a view different from hers. Powers is making me see that – does it scare you?” Erica challenged.

“Yeah, and your belly is already twice as big as mine because you ate so much tonight,” Emily pointed out. Erica's belly was in fact a bit distended past her waistband but it wouldn't have normally been a cause for notice. Erica knew this and just smiled contentedly as her sister rolled her eyeballs and marched off in a huff.

Meanwhile Mr. and Mrs. Mays were recalling the time to which Erica was alluding about five years before. Erica, already slender, had resolved to lose a few pounds while prepping for tryouts with the high school cheerleading team. Emily had teased her alleging that she was “fat,” which was hardly the truth, but she took it as such without consulting anyone. The remark made her aware of her “eat whatever suits me” behavior and she’d stopped eating a lot of her favorite dishes because she felt they were dangerous.

Frankly the change had bothered Claudia but she’d gone along with the initial request. Erica did lose 12 pounds, made the team and Emily felt empowered over her older sister. Over the next several years Emily became increasingly fatophobic and Erica had gone along.

Now things appeared to be were changing and Erica’s mom felt relieved at the direction. She’d privately been concerned about her daughter’s aversion to many foods and considered her to possibly be underweight. This an opinion shared by her husband who privately feared that Erica and Emily could become anorexic. He suggested that, in addition to the pre-prepared crepes and won ton shells Claudia perhaps should quietly add some ice cream quarts to the augmented freezer stash.
.
When the Proclaimer apology hit the next day Erica received a number of kind comments about her retraction. Even her fellow cheerleaders at Powers thought it good that she’d chosen to back off. As for Gary, he acted in class as though he hadn’t read it, simply remarking that he was looking forward to their evening and would pick her up around six. .

Erica felt liberated and was looking forward to the remainder of the week. She had no intention or desire to eat much more than normal, but she did enjoy giving herself the freedom to have what she felt like. Her Mom asked for meal planning suggestions and was pleasantly surprised when Erica responded by saying “Oh maybe Mexican or Italian – or, even better, its been ages since we had one of your casseroles.”
1413311211222111111112212222211211111122.title: Emily continues to harass Erica

Erica's sister catches her grazing their mom'snew  food cache
1413311211222111111112212222211211111122.content:
Erica the next morning decided to avoid her sister for breakfast by going to the Power’s dining hall. There she ran into her cheerleading captain Darlene Olmstead.

“Hey Erica,” said Darlene. “I’ve been wanting to talk with you – can we share breakfast?”

“Um, oh, I guess so,” stammered Erica, not quite knowing what to expect. Darlene surprised Erica by giving herself a generous breakfast of crepes, eggs and coffee. Erica cautiously followed her lead.

“I wanted to let you know how proud I was of you for apologizing and writing the retraction in the Proclaimer,” Darlene began after they were seated. . “And I think you’re ready for me to share my story.”

“What are you talking about?” asked Erica, totally confused. She had half-expected a lecture and was instead being treated as a confidant.

“I’m probably the heaviest cheerleader captain you’ve ever seen - good 35 pounds more than when I came to Powers. That’s why I put myself at the base of the pyramid this year; my thighs have filled out so much that they touch. You can’t see between them. Probably next year I won’t even be on the squad. Have you
noticed?”
“No, not really – I wasn’t here last year and you don’t look especially big on this campus.”

“Let’s be brutally honest,” Darlene said, “I’m on the way to becoming a new Power’s porker. If I wear my smaller clothes my belly already pooches slightly over the elastic of my waistband and my hips are starting to flare. Another twenty pounds and I’ll be showing love handles when eating breakfast.”

Wow,” responded Erica.” I really hadn’t thought about it, but you act as though none ofhis bothers you, its just a statement. Is that because your boyfriend Harold likes you bigger?””

“Well, that certainly helps,” replied Darlene, “but its only half the story. Unlike you I am here at Powers by intent and not surprised about what has happened with me. Harold and me happened after I arrived. I think you might find the back story interesting.

“OK,” replied Erica.

“It began with the day of my sister’s 18th birthday. I’m three year’s younger than her, which would mean I was fifteen. She wanted to wear a favorite dress which she loved from the day she got it. She walked to our room and started to don it by pulling it up from around her feet. Everything was fine until arriving at the belly, getting no further. It was barely four months since it had been given to her and then it had fit her perfectly.

“”Have I gained weight?” she wondered aloud to no one in particular. I knew better than to say anything, so held my tongue. She looked in the mirror and shrugged. Apparently to her it seemed the same like always. She may have considered the possibility that she’d been eating more food than normal. I don’t know. She had acquired a new boyfriend about six months before who enjoyed treating her, but was it even possible to outgrow a dress in only 16 weeks?”

“I suppose so,” said Erica, “But she would have had to really be pigging out I would think.”

“You are probably right,” remarked Darlene, “but I didn’t think she had been doing that. Still, as she stood there I considered the evidence of what had been going on for the previous few months. As the school year ended she had frequently studied with food at her side and for breakfast and supper generally had been eating bigger portions than me.

“Mom had noticed her clothes were getting snug, that’s why she’d bought sis a new wardrobe after graduation, including the dress. It was a size 10 – larger than what she’d worn before. But sis hadn’t really noticed.

“Anyway, it did not matter for the moment. The dress was not fitting, so she next grabbed her jeans, not wanting to waste time on her birthday. They too seemed tight and a bit uncomfortable – she’d been wearing shorts for most of the past six week of summer. Finally she decided to wear some leggings and an elastic shirt and joined our family and her boyfriend.

“We all went to eat at an Italian restaurant called Buca de Beppo and everything was buenisimo. The portions were huge and sis and her boyfriend plunged right in. Soon she was noting that her skirt was feeling snug. Still, she went ahead and had dessert at my family and boyfriend’s urging. This she later told me she regretted, because she realized that such enjoyment was the reason her clothes suddenly weren’t fitting.

“When she got home the first thing she did was get on the scale. Her weight had increased 8 kilograms since the beginning of the year, but she just hadn’t noticed it. She called her boyfriend, thinking he might have noticed and wondering why he hadn’t said anything. He said yes, she might have gained some but mot to worry - he liked it a lot what had happened.

“She initially wasn’t sure what to make of all this. Neither frankly did I. She thought it a bit odd that her boyfriend would like her body with 8 more kilograms, which is like 17 pounds. Then he really surprised her, saying that he would not mind if she fattened up a little more. This she found really weird but he suggested she search the Internet.”

“So what happened?” asked Erica.

“She did as he'd suggested,,” continued Darlene as she ate the last of her crepe. “and discovered a whole community of people who loved eating, or feeding. She decided her boyfriend was one of them, and realized that he had been encouraging her appetite even before she was given the dress. Since she loved the food she began considering whether gaining weight wasn’t really that bad ....

“They talked it over and decided they were both comfortable with both her appetite and the results. After that she began to eat until she was full and left off sports altogether as she went on to college.

“Naturally she got bigger every month, nearly sixty pounds over the next two years. She told me her boyfriend massaged her tummy, stroking, tapping gently and finally giving it a kiss.. She also got fed by him slowly in her mouth, which she savored with incredible pleasure.

“She loved those moments, which she shared with me. She loved those moments, but she and her boyfriend eventually went their separate ways. She continued her journey alone, which led her into transferring to Powers for her final year. Her most recent birthday dress was a size 24 after graduation.”

“And you?” asked Erica.

“My own attitude towards food and weight began to change from her example. I was fascinated by it but was locked into the regimen of high school. I shared and enjoyed some stuffings with her. It intrigued me but I held off until after my own graduation. Then during the summer I began to let myself relax, finally going along with a suggestion from my aunt that I try attending Powers and let my body seek its level.“

“And what happened?” Erica probed.

“I began creeping up slowly my freshman year. It wasn't that great because I do work out but, as you can tell, my body isn’t immune to a few pounds gained gradually. I’m nearly 150 now and while I don’t think I’ll be getting huge I feel better than I did at 125.”


“And the point of telling me all this?”

“Just to let you know that I appreciate your change of view – because I had to make a transition as well. You’ll decide, as I have, where you’re most comfortable and realize that others make their own choices as well.”

With that both girls realized that first period was approaching and disposed of their trash before moving on. Erica noted that her friend’s bellyassuredly wasn’t flat, its outline stretching against the fabric of her pants. As she turned Erica took especial note of Darlene’s derriere and nodded. The cheerleading captain definitely wasn’t skinny. Her hips and thighs weren't huge but had obvious extra padding – and her waist was bordering on thick.

Erica’s head was spinning as she realized that the transition Darlene had related could potentially apply to her as well.

Emily catches Erica enjoying their mom's new food cache and goes balistic
1413311211222111111112212222211211111122.content:
After Darlene’s discourse Erica wasn’t focused on the subject matter in class. She was instead observing the impact of Powers cuisine and lifestyle on her classmates.

Susan Peters was a good example. At the beginning of the year she had just been another face in the crowd, with a figure tending to plumpness but no larger than the average new Powers co-ed. However, since she habitually used a seat in first period caddy corner in front of Erica the calorie conscious observer had taken judgmental notice of Susan’s fulsome torso and somewhat larger than average butt.

“She’d better watch it or that fanny will bloom,” Erica had thought. And she had been right. About two months in she observed Susan having difficulties with her tank top and slacks, needing to adjust them whiner she rose from her chair,

One day Susan noticed Erica looking at her and quipped dismissively “yeah, they’re snug – must be putting on some weight. It happens to everyone in college I guess.”

“Everyone who doesn’t lay off the goodies,’ Erica had thought. But Susan didn’t seem bothered. Two weeks later she had a different set of clothes that fit better – and now they too were filling out.

All the student center food was definitely having an impact on Susan’s body, especially her lower half, and she knew it. She was, Erica realized, choosing to either accept her expansion or be in denial over it, Erica didn’t know which. Each morning Susan was finding it more difficult to stuff her rounding belly into her shorts. She would suck in her breath and pull, which worked for the moment. The problem was that it left a muffin top above the waistband and another roll beneath. While walking or standing this made no great difference, but in class her waistband would gradually work its way down behest the lower part of her belly.

Erica watched this unfolding struggle and held her peace, but it didn’t surprise her when Susan suddenly started wearing erring skirts to class.

Marge Downing by contrast was fat by any standard before coming to Powers. Friendly and congenial her belly was large enough that she had to spread her thighs to give it room when sitting down. But, Erica noticed, she was apparently accustomed to this and didn’t care. Her bras cut into the flesh of her backside and rolls that Erica leashed were called “love handles” by some adorned her sides.

Erica had seen Marge at a nearby table while she was taking with Darlene. She had a drink, large burrito, and some eggs. While chatting with two other Powers coeds in the 200+ range. Erica began to have the realization that, like Darlene and probably Susan and others Marge had embraced life in the fast lane, a path Erica’s sister Emily feared and loathed.

Erica skipped lunch, taking refuge in the nearly vacant library at that hour so that she could think. Her new friends, her mom and perhaps Gary the next evening were seemingly encouraging her to let go of her homage to the fatophobes, but what if Emily was right and she became huge? No answers came and she went hungry to her afternoon classes.

When Erica arrived home her mom was there – of itself a bit unusual. But she was cooking supper and invited Erica to have something from the pantry. She looked and noticed a breadbox, inside of which were several pastries. Her belly growling she settled for a bear claw and a large glass of milk. Then she confronted her mom.

“Mom, this pastry hits the spot and lasagna tonight? And I know you have ice cream in the freezer for dessert. You know I’m likely going to get stuffed by Gary tomorrow night because he’s from Powers. Aren’t you that concerned about upsetting Emily’s world?” she inquired.

Her mom sat down “It isn’t about Emily and you – its about you finding and making your own way. A few good sized meals isn’t going to add three pounds or three hundred, no matter what your sister says. But you need to be free to make your own choices. “Yes, there is ice cream in the freezer – but you can choose to skip it if you wish.”

“You don’t think I’ve been freely deciding these kind of things before?” Erica replied.

“Mo,” relied her mom. “None of us have, especially not Emily since she came under the influence of that fanatic teacher. We’ve all been intimidated into going along with a nanny-nanny approach for the sake of peace –but not because we really felt it was right and balanced. Powers in my view is at the other extreme, but where you decide to wind up should be your choice

“I think I understand and thanks mom,” said Erica as she finished her bear claw and headed to her room for a nap.

Later that night she had a single generous serving of lasagna to Emily’s dismay – and polished it off with a triple scoop of spumoni.

Emily attacks Erica's eating and feels her family has turned against her
1413311211222111111112212222211211111122.content:
Erica was deliberately late for breakfast Saturday morning, wanting to avoid confrontation with Emily. Her sister was gone as well as her Dad by the time she entered the vacant kitchen around 9:30. As she selected a banana to go with some cold grope nuts cereal her mom entered and offered to cook an omelet, but the slender freshman declined.

“I’m not sure what Gary has in mind for tonight but I need to be sure I have room in my belly,” she explained.

Her mom smiled. “He likes girls with an appetite?”

“I’ve no idea, but he is a guy at Powers so its possible.” Erica replied pleasantly.

“How well do you know him?” Claudia May enquired.

“Barely at all really, except across the room in class. The dining hall was crowded and I offered him a seat, that’s how we met. But he seems nice and friendly enough. Emily of course thinks he’s a typical Power’s chubby chaser who is going to turn me into a prize hog overnight,” Erica explained.

“Not on a single date, darling. I suggest you be fair and not prejudge him,” her mom replied.

“Of course – but I am learning that Powers does have a certain bias in their admissions policy. Some guys who like bigger girls do attend there deliberately. Some jerk from off-campus even got arrested for trying to “save” a new Freshman from being pulled into the vortex – I suppose you read about it,” noted Erica.

“Oh yes, Emily saw to that,” Mrs. Mays acknowledged, rolling her eyeballs. “But as you know he was a nut case from off campus, not part of the student body.

By the way, there are two blueberry and cheese Danishes from breakfast left over in the breadbox if you feel like having one.”
Eric was startled at the abrupt change of subject. Was her Mom trying to get her to eat more? She simply smiled and said thank you, deciding not to explore the topic further. But around noon, with her mom gone, she remembered the offer and had one for a snack. Then she texted Gary for guidance on what to wear – wondering where they were headed.

“Choice of three, none of them super fancy – but you will do the deciding,” he replied cryptically. See you at five.”

“Hmmm,” thought Erica, “I guess I can get away with wearing my mid-length dark blue cotton cargo shorts. With six pockets I won’t need to carry my bill fold. Yes, with a belt and white top it should be acceptable anywhere and it looks college rather than formal.”

That decided Erica lay down for a nap. When she awoke shortly after three she found herself thinking of the reaming blueberry Danish. As she retrieved it from the kitchen she thought mischievously “I can imagine what Emily would say if she saw me doing this.”

Gary showed up on schedule and as promised offered Erica her choice of three destinations: “Cracker Barrel southern style, Jose Pepper’s Tex Mex or Town and Country American family – all good, but three different palates.”

“Honestly?” replied Erica, “I’ve only been to one of them, but that was ten years ago at least as a kid. Didn’t Jose Pepper get started in Wichita?”

“Yes.” replied Gary, “that they did. Now they’re a chain with stores from here to Kansas ty. So, that’s your choice?”

“I guess so,” replied Erica, wondering what was in store.

“So be it,” answered Gary. “And if things go well the others can be visited another time.”

As they drove the approximately 30 miles to Jose Pepper’s original site Gary asked Erica some general questions about her classes. She replied in kind, learning that he knew computers, stayed current on geopolitics and was majoring in business administrator. She began to wonder if he was so cerebral that he’d not even read the Proclaimer or had any idea of the furor she’d caused.

“The last time I was here I had a pair of their avocado and chicken enchiladas,” Gary volunteered. “They were topped with jalapeno cream sauce and garnished with guacamole. Best of all, they came with the usual Mexican rice and refried beans, but the beans were “lard free”, which is unusual for a Tex-Mex restaurant. Of course you can have anything on the menu you want.

Erica was already getting hungry but was at a loss as to how to reply.

What about tacos and burritos?” she inquired, reflecting her limited knowledge of cuisine...

“They have those, and chimichangas as well, even chili rellanos. If you want there’s a huge sampler but you’ll probably wind up taking half it home,” he commented.

Erica quietly decided to avoid the sampler, but found herself looking forward to the dinner.

Once at Jose Peppers Gary ordered chile con queso to go with the complimentary tortilla chips. Gary then ordered his avocado enchiladas and Erica wound up with a burrito, enchilada and taco combo. She was astonished when it arrived with the same sides as Gary’s order. She had expected to be a la carte.

“Just eat when you can and take the rest home,” he counseled. “Places like this expect it.”

By that time Erica had volunteered the Proclaimer issue and told Gary about Emily. He’d admitted to having made the link after he’d already asked her but felt it was a closed issue so why bother rehashing it. As for Emily, she obviously had her own issues to resolve. He seemed more concerned about his world view and that of Erica.

Erica took her time but after consuming about two-thirds she confessed she was ready to pack the rest. Gary grinned and said “so be it – and I hope you liked it.”

“Oh definitely,” replied Erica. “I can see where girls can gain some weight being treated like this.”

“Not unless they do it every day – dining out should be a special time, not something to be feared,” he replied. “It’s what people do regularly and what their body make up is that determines such things – not everyone is the same. At least that’s what the studies at Rockefeller University indicate.

Erica took a deep breath. She knew how tight her cargo shorts belt felt – she had stuffed herself silly. But it had been enjoyable.

“So you’re not into this obesity epidemic thing that has so many concerned?” she asked.

“If the cure has to be feeding children the slop that’s being forced down kid’s throats with this school lunch program, no way,” he answered. “Have you seen the pictures they’re posting on Twitter?”

“No, but I’ve heard they’re pretty bad,” Erica admitted.

“Its nanny government gone wild,” Gary asserted. “Kid’s shouldn't be made to feel guilty about enjoying meals – minimizing the sugar and salt is fine, but not this genetically modified fare with chemical additives.”

Erica found herself agreeing with both his statement and passion. She began to see more clearly just how far off Ms Stennis and Emily were. But she elected not
to develop that topic any further for the moment. Gary helped her by shifting to another topic.

Overall Erica had a great evening – one where food was factor but not the whole focus. Erica went home feeling she and Gray would be seeing more of each other – and if she gained a few pounds it was none of Emily’s concern. She felt confident that her mom and dad had her back on that one. What she didn’t fully realize was that Gary, who found her to be a sweet if somewhat naive girl he was attracted to, was fully aware of how much she’d consumed. Between the appetizer, entrée and two large non diet sodas she’d packed way nearly 800 more calories than he had – not counting the take home leftovers.

He smiled contentedly all the way back to Powers.
1413311211222111111112212222211211111122.title: Dinner date time

choices: Erica has another evening with Madison and friends
Emily and Mrs Stennis try to reclaim their fallen soldier
1413311211222111111112212222211211111122.content:
Erica arrived home full but contented. Emily to her relief was nowhere in sight – and her parents were sharing popcorn in front of the TV. They invited her to join in, but she declined – she didn’t care about the program and was too stuffed to snack. She put the leftovers in the refrigerator and retried to her bedroom.

There she sat down at her desk, the computer monitor off to relax and contemplate. . She reviewed the evening with Gary and felt good about it. She texted him “thks for erytng – I’ll slp wl 2nite.”

With that she went to bed, removed her clothes for a nightgown and turned out the light. But she was restless, her mind wrestling with the contrast between Gary’s approach and that of her younger sister. She realized that she needed to makeup her own mind – but what actually did she want?

Before losing those 12 pounds and falling into her sister’s web she’d never been truly heavy – just a little thicker than some. And it hadn’t bothered her to have a piece of pie or seconds on a casserole. Then she’d paid a price to make the cut for cheerleading – but she now realized something strange had happened along the way. Feeling deprived herself she’d become judgmental of others. And that, she now realized was wrong.

She thought of a onetime friend, Jennifer, who’d taken anther path and tried to warn her, but she’d cut ties rather than listen.

“No one says that you need to hangout on at McDonalds and clean the board with their dollar menu,” Jennifer Wiggins had said. “Personally I prefer Salisbury steak sandwiches homemade. But we’re growing teens and shouldn’t be starving ourselves.”

She’d watched Jennifer make her choice – her thighs and bulbous butt growing a little more bountiful with every after school snack and lunchtime extra pastry. But it was a slow gradual process and Jennifer seemed either not to notice or simply not care. She had no self-hatred or loathing towards her body even as her belly developed into a roll that was plainly visible through whatever she wore. But as her neck and arms followed her thickening torso and she began developing a softer chin Jennifer simply changed her hairstyle to a ponytail and kept on eating, which at the time infuriated Erica

Another year passed and Erica wasn’t talking to Jennifer, who’d by then acquired a boyfriend (something Erica never seemed to attract). The tight waistband of Jennifer’s slacks by then was creating a muffin top even when standing. She changed wardrobes, but not her eating habits. On occasion she would glance at Erica picking at her usual salad with Emily and shake her head sadly as she paraded by with a tray of spaghetti or Mexican lasagna. But then the school cafeteria went to prepackaged “healthy meals” and laid off their cooks.

Jennifer had become one of Emily’s “hogs” at probably 170-180 pounds by graduation, but somehow Erica had sensed that her former friend was happier – and friskily attractive both in her prom dress and graduation gown. But she’d moved on and was now attending college at Stanford while Erica was at Powers.
Finally, after midnight, Erica fell asleep – quietly angry at having allowed Emily to so control her destiny. She slept until late in the morning. Both Emily and her parents were gone; Erica went to the refrigerator and finished her meal from the night before but didn’t feel full. She went to the freezer and retrieved a half-gallon container of cherry vanilla ice-cream, making it the foundation of a homemade banana split replete with strawberry jam, and some rainbow sprinkles.

Erica was cleaning up just after 11:00 when her mm arrived home and offered to make lunch. She declined, saying she’d just fished breakfast using the leftovers from the night before (but not mentioning the extra dessert).

“Sounds fine by me – your Dad and I had burritos at IHOP – then he went over to Jack Rivers place and I went shopping,” her mom remarked. “:I guess things went well last night?”

“Yes,” Erica acknowledged, “But if Gary and I start dating Emily’s going to fuss when I gain back those 12 pounds –plus probably some more. He’s with you and Dad – be myself, and weight choices shouldn’t be anyone else’s business but that of the one carrying the pounds. But I suspect he’ll make choosing food an easy choice.”

Claudia Mays smiled knowingly, “and you seem happy about that.”

“Strangely, within reason, yeah,” Erica replied. “It won’t happen overnight but you’re going to likely see a thicker Erica – whether Miss Stennis and Emily like it or
not.”

Claudia smiled again. “Your dad will be happy to hear that. There have been tines he’s worried you could go anorexic.”

“Anorexics loathe their bodies and see themselves as fat and ugly even when their way underweight. I’ve never hated my body, but was just conforming, so I don’t think it was ever a danger,” Erica replied.

“I know that honey, but if you need a new wardrobe just let me know,” her mom replied.

Erica was a little taken back by that statement but her grazing the next week did reflect a new attitude. She made a point of having lunch at t he same time as Gary and letting him see that he was following Powers tradition in food choices. At home she several times had late evening snacks, ignoring Emily’s censorious glare. And just to rub things in she replaced her usual grape nuts breakfast with more substantial omelets and higher calorie cinnamon toast crunch cold cereal. Her mom took due notice, as well as the fact that some ice-cream had been used from the freezer.

The next weekend was the tournament. Powers finished first in 5 of the 12 events, including the teams headed by Madison and Jeff. They came in second or third in four others, garnering enough points to win the tournament – and for Erica another dinner date with Gary in celebration.
