Sandra was hungry by the time they finished up at the police station, so she pestered him into the dinner plans, when he revealed where they were going for dinner.

"We're going to Ray's," he remarked,

"Ah, and what might that be??"

"It's a BBQ buffet, it's well known around Powers for the awesome food, so you'd be advised to learn about it early."

"Well, anything that helps me adjust to the Powers University culture, I suppose."

As they walked over, Robert noticed that her food baby had receded, and he wondered if he could get it filled up again. His buffet choice was no coincidence, he figured that this would help him in that goal. When they got in the restaurant, Sandra was engrossed by the amazing smell, something common for those in the restaurant for the first time. There were rows of ribs, wings, steak, burgers...pretty much any meat based food you could want, they had. Sandra skipped the salad bar and went straight to the meats.

"Man, you know you can make two trips, Sandra," Robert casually joked, while looking at the pile of food on Sandra's plate.

"Yeah, I know, this all just looks amazing and I can't help it. But yeah, at some point I need to slow down, I already ate too much this morning, can't make this the norm!"

Robert almost took it internally as some kind of challenge, since he found the mock concern by Sandra endearing. For most of the time, through Sandra's first two plates, they talked about the Bud Ramsey developments, and their happiness with his being identified. They both hoped that they could get the entire event behind them at some point. Eventually, they exhausted conversation on that and they moved on while Sandra was up getting her third plate. When she sat back down, Robert tried to segway into other topics.

"So you know magic tricks?"

"Yes," Sandra said in between the finishing bites on some fried chicken

"Can you do any right now for me?"

"Ok. Watch this rib," she pulled a large rib off Robert's plate, "disappear before your very eye!" Sandra quickly scarfed it down. Robert chucked, "Man," he thought, "she is really attacking this food."

As they were getting ready to go, she had to readjust her pants again to accommodate her food baby. It was bulging, and the softness still felt off for Sandra. Robert on the other hand, felt like he had achieved his goal, well today at least he did.

As Mark and Jessica drove towards their rendezvous with Jim and Madison he filled her in on the procedure in the lineup. It had been an updated modern version of the black box arrangement seen in old movies. There those at one end under bright lights in a long room were effectively blinded and prevented from seeing those viewing them.

“Now,“ explained Mark, “they use a wall divider with a reverse mirror window. Its totally sound proof and takes up less area. But I found out something you will find interesting – this guy’s a suspect in two disappearances. No bodies yet, so he hasn’t been charged, but the M.O. is similar – Sandra and Allison may be very lucky.”

“Whew,” replied Jessica. “and poor Sandra – all she thinks she has to worry about is gaining a few pounds.”

“What do you mean?” Mark responded with surpise.

“In the waiting room she was done with Ramsey. She instead was fussing over having eaten so much last week with all the stuff I’d left her to enjoy. Its improved her appetite so she got stuffed at lunch again today. She’s not seen the results – yet, but fears they’re coming. And the way she packs it away she’s not wrong.”

Mark rolled his eyeballs. “Well, if I have Robert pegged right she’ll soon be over that hump. Did you notice him making sure she was cared for at the party?”

“Oh yes – just like someone else I know. You aren’t coaching him or anything, are you?” questioned Jessica.

“No way. I only met hi last week. He hooked up with Sandra on his own because of how she was eating the free breakfasts. She does have an appetite.” Mark observed.

“Yes, I’ve noticed. She’s trying to cut back now but as I’ve learned that’s not easy once you get to enjoy eating I think she has a bigger capacity than me, if you can believe it. Speaking of which, I think we’re almost ready to meet our dinner partners.” concluded Jessica.

They parked Mark’s car and went into the Bella Luna Cafe, a Mediterranean style restaurant rated as one of the best in the Witchita area. Madison had concurred in an uncredited review she’d written the year before, calling it “pricy on some items but worth every penny.”

After the foursome linked up Jim immediately ordered a Hummus Shawarmah appetizer for everyone to share while they mulled their choices. It included sliced chicken marinated in vinegar and spices with
parsley and pine nuts. He’d promised to treat for the entrees as long as entrée choices were kept to $12 or less.

Jim went for the pasta Diablo, flavored with peppers and onions in a roasted tomato cream sauce. Madison would have preferred the more expensive braised lamb shank but settled for beef curry and rice. Mark went with Bella Luna’s signature steak sandwich which comes with a pasta salad. Jessica, ever the lover of Italian dishes, hungrily ordered the six cheese pasta, a dish including Mascarpone, Fontina, Gorgonzola, Swiss, Pecorino Romano & Parmigiano-Reggiano Cheeses tossed with tomato and spinach.

While they waited for their order to arrive Madison listened quietly while Mark related the day’s events – including the possible link of Bud Rasey to actual crimes. Wenhed finished she and Jim glancedat each other. She’d told him erlier she’d go head with thea yet unannounced promotion and now thery both understood the implctins of wehsat Msrk had shsred.

“Mark, I have one question. Is there any reason why it has taken this long to piece things together?” Madison asked.

“We live in one town, Ramsey’s in another, and campus security takes care of the college. I guess its lack of coordination,” suggested Mark. “Why, for instance, aren’t the police aware of Alison having been approached – or, if they are, wasn’t she called in today?”

“Exactly. Why doesn’t local law enforcement use Go to Meeting or some such to compare notes and connect dots better. The bad guys opeerate across jurisdictions – why can’t law enforcement?” she asked.

“”Privacy and confidentiality?” suggested Jessica,

“Definite factors – but should they be the overriding ones?” broke in Jim

Madison continued her thought train. “Mark, if the campus paper were to run a story on Alison and Sandra and what you did today would you mind? Especially if it were part of a campaign to get better cooperation?” asked Madison.

“Since when is the Proclaimer the crusading agent for change?” he replied

“Since Professor Hastings said it should be – like this semester. And this sounds like something we could jump on, right Mr. Associate Publisher?” she said looking at Jim. The others suddenly caught on.

“The new Features Editor has spoken. And personally I agree.” returned Jim.

“My question is willingness to put up with the attention this will bring? I think Alison, Sandra and maybe others would be better off for it.” Madison declared.

Jessica and Mark also realized something else – as good as the use of recent events might be the stress wouldn’t suppress Sandra’s appetite. Alison’s response, however, was unpredictable. Right now she was planning on exercising more with Kelsey.

As the meal drew to a close, Mark offered to pay for the desserts and beverages since Jim had done the appetizer and entrees. They were both proud of their well-fed and rounded girlfriends.

It seemed to be a soft, non-rolled, fleshy mound under the tight shirt that Liz was wearing. She wondered if this was temporary, of if what Liz had previously mentioned regarding her weight was going to be a reoccurring event. Regardless, Allison didn't want her weight to follow the trend at the school, or at least among the girls she knew already. Allison loved her current body, and although not as judgmental as Kelsey, she had no desire to gain any weight.

Kelsey came into the room after that.

"Hey ladies, what have you been up to?"

"Ah. I see." Kelsey noted, somewhat annoyed, "well I just got done with my workout, I love to get that stuff out of the way." Allison didn't know that Kelsey had done that already, "rats!" thought Allison, "now I'll have to workout on my own." 153112211121121111211.content:
Liz fidgeted a bit over Alison and Kelsey’s banter about lunch and exercise. She knew she’d slimmed down from where she once had been but was already eating more at Powers, not just at lunch today but generally. It wasn’t deliberate, and it wasn’t enough she felt to be showing, but just rooming with Calli made her more undisciplined.

On Sunday for example Liz had brought home a box of 6 pastries expecting them to last until Monday morning. By bedtime she’d devoured four and shared two with Calli, who had prepared two meals that day herself which she’d shared with Liz. Lunch had been a quarter poundrr deluxe value meal at McDonalds.

Liz keenly remembered all of this when she said she and Allison had indulged at lunch. It was true enough but not the whole picture. And she felt Alison could tell that she still had some soft flesh from her previous size – regaining it could occur quickly, but she knew that would likely bring criticism from Kelsey.

Alison’s statement was more honest. Unlike Liz she’d skipped breakfast, then devoured a plate of spaghetti with meatballs and two chicken thighs plus a large soda. Then Liz, who’d eaten similarly, had suggested cookies for dessert and brought her two large tollhouse delicacies. She knew it was a bundle of calories but she’d honestly expected to work them off th Kelsey.

Liz decided to go on the offensive to distract attention from herelf, asking Kelsey “Are you planning on going out for one of the teams? Is that why you exercise so much? You sound like an athlete”

“Well, yes,” acknowledged Kelsey, “ I originally came here to be part of the soccer team as a wak-on but then they changed coaches and I gor frozen out too late to go elsewhere, But I have another school locked up if I do well in my classes this yesr.”

“I suspected that, “ replied Liz, “I’d never have the skills or discipline for that but I admire you for it. Power’s loss is going to be that school’s gain.”

“I’m glad for your encouragement,” Kelsey said a little condescendingly . Liz seemed a little thick to her, definitely not soccer msterial. She was a nice person though and she had no reason to criticize her.

Alison listened to the exchange with another view. She had become aware the night before of her roommate Madison’s pending big announcement and was surprised someone that heavy could be so well regarded. But just talking with the big girl for the past week had convinced her she had brains and wasn’t lazy. Discrimination by the athletic department sounded like just the kind of crusade Madison might be looking for. So Alison decided to ask “what would happen if the student body and alumni discovered that you’d been frozen out? Would you be embarrassed if someone started a campaign to get you included?”

“Like what are you talking about?” Kelsey asked, intrigued but uncertaim.

“My roommate said the school paper is looking to spice things up a bit with controversy. She’s probably going to be Feature Editor and this sounds like a story” Allison volunteered.

Kelsey thought of Madison, whom she regarded as simply a 200 pound whale not in her league. Could someone that big actually be able to help her? She didn’t want to be unkind but the idea seemed preposterous.

“Would I like see some justice? Of course. But let’s face it, Madison’s a porker. Who is going to take her seriously.?” answered Kelsey.

“That’s ridiculous,” snapped Liz. “I used to be bigger myself and it had nothing to do with my abilities and talents elsewhere. You shouldn’t put someone down just because they’re not like you. Why not let Alison ask?”

Kelsey realized she’d gone too far. So many of the students here were either fat or kindly disposed towards those whe were. She sighed and said, “alright. Excuse my skepticism and see what she can do. But I’m not optimistic.”

“Thank you,” replied Alison quietly. She wasn’t anywhere near as antagonistic to people of size as Kelsey. She just knew that her own goal was an Ivy League school and being bigger wasn’t going to help get there. But she had already developed a respect for Madison. .

“Speaking of optimism,” said Liz to change the subject, “We had 5-6 guys at the party Saturday. I gave my number and email to four of them and have heard back from two with one date. “

“I save out four as well and have one date” replied Alison.

“I haven’t checked my email and my cell phone battery was dead yesterday. I don’t remember how many I gave out,” answered Kelsey, who wasn’t quite telling the truth. At the party he’d been dumbfounded by the food an atmosphere, choosing to sit by herself and not mix in. She’d only had two guys try to talk with her and had given both the cold shoulder. She felt Sandra’s magic tricks, Alison’s Karaoke and Liz’s instrumental solo were attention getting gimmicks that were beneath her. She was there for appearances without consuming and gainging weight – something everyone else seemed not to care about.

“OK,” said Alison. “I need to get back to my room and do some study.”

“Me too,” said Liz, aware that in her desk was a half finished packet of coconut macaroons. She felt like nibbling on some before sdupper, whatever Calli was preparing.

Kelsey said nothing as the others took off. She knew she weighed twenty pounds less than either of them, but at Powers it didn’t seem to matter. She recalled that the night before her overweight roomie Kelli had offered her a cream-covered bagel. She had of course turned it down

In the morning it had been the same. Kelli had invited Kelsey to join Mike and for breakfast but she’d declined. And she knew Aison wanted to exercise, but she felt she couldn’t wait and besides might slack off as Alison wasn’t as committed. Kelsey felt lonely. It seemed everyone else was circling in a different orbit than her and their solar system revolved around food.

1531122111211211112111.content:
In a manner that wasn't atypical of freshman year, most of the guys who got numbers from girls were from the same group of friends. Liz, Allison, and Kelsey were not the only girls there, but there was enough socializing going on that there was some overlap. On the top floor of the same freshman dorm that Madison had been in a year ago, Kevin got a knock on his door.

"It's unlocked!" he shouted as him and his roommate Eric were in a tight battle on their game counsel against some foes online.

"Sup, guys, how's that game going." Clark asked his two new buddies.

"Eh, ever since we got bumped up a level, we have been getting sloughtered." Erick replied

"Ha, bet you're getting owned by a pack of 12 year olds back from class."

"Most likely." Neither Eric nor Kevin were the type to get too into video games, but used them as a fun time suck.

In the first weekend, Eric and Kevin became friends. Both were from suburbs about 4 hours away, in different directions from Powers. They were typical guys who grew up in upper middle class households, likeable, but never the king of the class by any means, just typical. Eric was about 6 ft tall, and Kevin was 5'11, each were average build. Clark was a tad shorter, and from a rural area, but they were all hitting it off.

"So what did you all think of the party?" Clark asked, as Eric reached over to power off the game.

"It was alright, maybe we want to go to something a bit more wild in the future," remarked Eric. "Yeah, agreed," added Kevin.

"What makes you say that? I did okay, I got that girl Liz's number," remarked Clark.

"Well yeah she seemed pretty eager, didn't she," Eric noted, "I mean not that it's a bad thing, I guess that's kind of what college is about. Did you do well, Kev?"

"Yeah, that girl Allison gave me her number, we're going to grab dinner together in the dinning hall later this week. She seemed pretty cool. Plus, we both have played a bit of tennis in our past, although I think she's better than me."

"Nice. Hey, should we be alarmed that all the sophomores looked, you know...bigger?" Eric asked, being honest, and not overly critical about the question.

"Yeah, I noticed that as well," Kevin responded.

Neither Kevin nor Eric, or really even Clark preferred larger women. They wouldn't be overly mean to a larger girl, they just probably would want to avoid dating them. It was for a variety of reasons, first, they didn't know if they would be physically into that, and secondly, for social reasons, they didn't really want to go that direction, plus third, in high school, there were not that many larger girls. Lots of fast metabolisms and controlling parents kept waistlines thin, as Madison and Cassi found out last year.

One thing that was universally reflected on by the guys was that Kelsey as pretty hot, but she seemed distant, and rather intimidating, so no one made a pass on her. It was hard to say if she would have decided to go out with any of them, but her demeanor meant that she didn't have the chance.

15311221112112111121112.content:
On Tuesday evening Alison strolled into the Powers University dining hall wearing well fitting auburn colored slacks and a striped top. The country girl wanted to make a good impression on Kevin, whom she’d met at the party only four days before. Other than the fact that he came from the suburbs, played at tennis and seemed friendly enough she knew nothing about him. Of course, she realized, that applied to him as well.

Kevin had arrived a few moments earlier, equally nervous and not wanting to mess up his first date in college. He was about three inches taller than the lithe 5’9”Alison and suspected she was better at tennis than him, but he hoped they’d find other common interests. What he wanted was a girl who was down to earth, intelligent, idealistic while at the same time realistic, unlike the boring pretentious airheads in high school – hung up on appearance and personalities with no substance.

At the same time he was curious. Alison at the party seemed totally accepting of the larger girls there, particularly her roommate Madison, yet herself ate like an athlete – only having one burger, some salad and a single dessert. Others, particularly Sandra, seemed to be eating every second. But Alison was ignoring all that, focused on getting to know the new guys. That’s why she and Kevin had exchanged numbers.

“Well, hello there,” he said, coming up behind her, “Right on time I see.”

“Yes, my mom trained me to be punctual. Classes let out four hours ago which gave Kelsey and I a chance to run today. I hadn’t done it since Friday and really needed it. Then I got ready for us,” she replied.

“Well then let’s get some food and we’ll find a table. Things aren’t apparently as busy now as at lunch and breakfast,” noted Kevin.

“Probably because the meal plan only allows for two meals a day, you pay extra for a third. Morning and lunch are the easiest to have because you’re tired in the morning and too rushed at noon. But in the evening you can have groups on your own. Or at least that’s what I’m told.” related Alison.

The two freshman went through the line, Alison resisting the emptation to have spaghetti and meatballs with French bread and settling on a taco salad topped with guacamole and a burrito. Kevin went for meatloaf, potatoes and green beans. They both had soft drinks, Kevin noting that Alison was selecting moderate items suitable for one into athletics. He thought “Not much likelihood she’ll become a plumper even if her dorm is filled with them.”


He then felt awkward about this thought. He knew it should be none of his business, but the discussion in the dorm had intrigued him. Why was this he started to wonder, but then suppressed his brain for the moment, shifting the subject. .

“I enjoyed your guitar playing Saturday,” he noted. “I wish at times I’d learned to play an instrument but I never had the discipline,”

“Well its nothing formal. I picked it upas part of a church program and know enough to be dangerous with a ballad, but I’ll leave the really fast stuff to the experts,” Alison replied.

“So you’re a church girl? My family is Baptist,” Kevin said. “Some people unfortunately think of us a bible thumpers. Actually we just listen to sermons and then have potlucks.”

There he went again, bringing up food.

Why is this going on? he wondered.

“Thumping a bible doesn’t do much – reading it can if you want it to,” answered Alison, watching to see Kevin’s reaction as she continued eating her supper. ..

Kevin laughed, “you’re right on with that. Actually I’ve never seen a Baptist or anyone else actually thump a bible. But doing justice, loving mercy and walking humbly before God I’ve heard about plenty.”

“Yes, Micah 6:8 as I recall – a Baptist who knows the old testament. I guess I should be impressed.” noted Alison.

“OK – and I suppose that’s why you’re at Powers – it has a conservative heritage and no booze in the dorm parties.” probed Kevin.

Alison shook her head “No, just plenty of food – like your Baptist potlucks. Actually I’m at Powers because my grandparents are footing the tuition. They made their’s before the bottom fell out of the economy and this is where my grandmother attended. She taught school for forty years, so it at least helped her. Me, I’m torn – I like the small town but the big city is supposed to be the future, at least monetarily.”

“You sound like you’re not really in love with the big city” replied Kevin

“I’m not. But 80% of the shops in our town have closed in the last ten years. And the assembly factories are kaput – jobs gone overseas. I’m not sure the big city is any better tough,” she said

“Is that why you weren’t eating as much as your friends Saturday? Life has you depressed?” inquired Kevin.

“No, that’s not the reason. I’m just not into food like some – but I’m not critical of them either. After a;l, they all have guys and I’m still looking, right?” she observed.

“True, but I can tell you it surprised some of the other guys and me. I wonder how they came together?” mused Kein.

“Well, four people, four stories. Callie’s always been big, Madison tried to help her and found out she and Jim enjoy life in the fat lane, Jessica I’m not sure about yet, Kelli’s making Michael happy but is still in denial l, if you can believe it. But as long as I watch myself and workout with Kelsey I’m likely to avoid joining them. As for Sandra and Liz, who knows?” Alison rambled.



'‘So none of them are trying to lose anything,” Kevin said with a look of amazement.

“Nope, Why should they? They’re happy, have guys, and it’s a pain trying o fight our metabolism and appetite. Madison’s mote concerned with helping Kelsey’s career than er own waistline.

“What do you mean?” asked Kevin.

Alison summarized Kelsey’s soccer ambitions and Madison’s new role.

“I think you’ll see a story in the campus paper by next week,” she concluded. “If she needs my help she has it – anyone should be given a chance and this new coach is just being unfair.”

By this time they’d both finished their meals and Kevin offered to get Alison a dessert but she declined, remarking “exercising only burns off so many calories and I’ve probably had more than my share today. But thank you for the nice dinner – we can do it again sometime if you want”

Kevin accepted her refusal and appreciated her offer. He wasn’t into bigger girls especially but part of him had wanted to give her a treat and he sensed she wasn’t full, just being disciplined. But he walked her back to her room and promised to see her again.

Kevin would have been surprised to know that after he left Alison went immediately to the refrigerator where a large slice of left over cherry cheesecake was calling to her,

153112211121121111211122.content:
Alison had texted Liz “Told Madison about Kelsey. She’s checking it out.”“

Good. Drop by this evening for supper and tell me all about it.” Liz had shot back.

“6:00 OK?” asked Alison.

“Perfect. I’ll have chicken pot pies in the oven. Callie won’t be home,” Liz replied

“Great,” thought Alison, ”more calories to work off. It’s good that I’m doing things with Kelsey."

Kelsey had expressed amazement to Alison at the decadent bliss of Kelli, who seemed to still be oblivious to her growing girth. She had described her torso as being ”like a bloated wine barrel under the eaves of two breasts.

“She walks around with her breast thrusting out, as if she doesn’t realize her belly rolls are out nearly as far. The slabs of back fat are getting creases, but she struts around as if its nothing. Then she lays half naked on her bed like Cleopatra watching TV munching on stuff, ” Kelsey had continued.

Madison had confided to Alison that Kelli was truly in denial over her size, which was probably within thirty pounds of her own. Alison hadn’t responded because it was really none of her concern, but she understood where Kelsey was coming from.

Alison’s own breakfast had been light, two slices of French toast and some melon slices. Lunch had been a tuna salad after the text invitation from Liz. Her workout had been a good 45 minutes. She felt ok having a good sized supper, but she wondered a bit about Liz, who had seemed a little softer on Sunday.

Liz really that wasn’t concerned about whether she regained some of her lost weight or not. But she was concerned about Madison and what Alison had done to help Kelsey, What had been done to the would-be soccer player wasn’t fair. And if it meant sharing a high calorie meal with Madison’s roommate to find out the details she’d gladly pay the price.

Liz was all smiles when she welcomed Alison in and seated her at the table.

“Dinner will be ready in a few minutes” she announced. There were two generous pineapple and cottage cheese salads already set out along with place settings and a carafe of tea. She brought out a colander of mashed potatoes. The pot pies were cooling on the counter. Using gloves she flipped them onto plates and brought them steaming to the table.

“Look good?” she asked

“Yes,” replied Alison, mentally calculating the laps it would take to work off this spread.

“OK,” then, dig in and tell me what’s going on,” Liz inquired.

Alison began aerating the pot pie by mixing in the cooler mashed potatoes while she delivered her report. “Well, Jim researched Kelsey’s records in school – respectable but nothing spectacular. But what she says about the rules being changed after she was accepted at Powers and having another offer for next year are both true. The story will run tomorrow in the sports page of the Proclaimer with the main lead being the creep who accosted Sandra in the cafeteria. It seems there’s a lack of communication between law enforcement departments around here.”

Liz listened intently with satisfaction. “Good. Its time people started taking notice of these things.”

“Yes, and this supper is great. I’m glad for working out with Kelsey or I might pack on a few pounds,” replied Alison.

“Tell me about it,” said Liz. “I think I’ve regained about five already. Living with a confident BBW like Calli can be contagious.”

“I can believe it,” agreed Alison, who now had confirmation that her prior observations hadn’t just been her imagination. “I’m glad I’m hanging with Kelsey and Kevin – by the way, have you heard from Clark?”

“Oh yeah,” replied Liz. “We’ve talked twice and even had lunch today. He’s from the country and a little shy. He tried to ask me diplomatically about our dorm full of chubsters. I think he was surprised to find out I’ve been one,”

“Really? Did that bother him?” asked Allison.

“I think he’s more puzzled than bothered. He told me I wasn’t heavy to him, certainly not like our hosts Saturday. But then he said they seemed to be nice and together people and he just needed to get used to people being different in the city. He wasn’t down on them at all,” answered Liz

“Hmmm, but I bet he didn’t offer to get you dessert.” Alison commented.

“No, We both had burgers with sides. Mine was potato salad and cold slaw; he had French fries. I would have had a slice of pie if he’d offered but it didn’t happen.” Liz replied.

“Hmmm. I bet Callie’s place is packed with enough of that kind of food anyway.” Alison said.

“Not really, Callie cooks great and has healthy portions but doesn’t have a lot of desserts or snack foods. I think she’s trying to level off and just not get any bigger. After all, she’s close to 230” disclosed Liz.

“That much?” Alison said, surprised but not overly so. “I’m surprised she’d share that.”

“She did, just in passing. Her mind isn’t on her weight as much as it is caring about kids. She does great with them, according to Tom. They make a good team and he doesn’t mind her size at all. That’s what I hope will happen for me some day,” ventured Liz.

“You want to be bigger again? After losing like what, forty pounds” Alison said with surprise.

“Or maybe a little more – I’m not exactly sure how much I lost. I’m not pushing to gain it back, but let’s be real: it will likely happen and I don’t care. I wasn’t unhappy before but just wanted to life easier with my mom and friends. But I know the stats Liz confided.

“And to all of this Clark said what?” Alison asked.

“Nothing. I didn’t get into this kind of detail with him. We split for classes after lunch and that was that. But he did text me afterwards and said he hoes we can do something again. So he’s not out of the picture. And now that we’ve finished the pot pie I do have some ice cream to share before Calli gets back and finds out I bought it.” Liz said with a sly grin.

Alison started to decline, but realized that after the hot supper it really did sound delicious. After polishing off a generous four scoop bowl with topping she went back to her own apartment.

1531122111211211112111222.content:
Yes,” responded Michael to Eric’s question, he two plus Clark and Kevin were having a dorm discussion. “I’m happy with Kelli being just the size she is, but it isn’t the cornerstone of our relationship. Guys like Robert and Mark are the true connoisseurs of the Ruebenesque – I don’t think they’ve even considered dating anyone who doesn’t have a good appetite.”

“Well, I guess Robert’s hit the jackpot with Sandra. She’s a terror on the buffet line,” wise cracked Kevin

“And you’re already expecting it to start showing – right.” Inquired Michael.

“Well like, yeah, duh – isn’t that obvious?” Kevin replied.

“The logic yes – but you have a hint of anticipation in your expression. I never had that with Kelli because I was already close to her. She did herself in by ragging on her roommate who then started cooking for her knowing she couldn’t resist. I knew it would make her less judgmental to gain few, but I didn’t anticipate what append.”

“Are you implying I could fall for a chubby chick?” Kevin said. He didn’t dislike heavier girls but in his peer group that just wasn’t done. College seemed to be different.

“I’m stating it as a fact – not that it will, but that it could. . And what’s so bad if it happens? Especially if they lift you up and are fun to share life with? Kelli was thin but her Mom is bigger than Callie – and with her hips she could be too eventually. Doesn’t bother me. Now if she were downcast and having to be propped up all the time that would be another thing.

“I went out with Allison. I think she’s too strict with herself to ever gain much," Kevin remarked

“You could be right – and nothing wrong with that. In fact if you have a problem with heavier chicks someone like Allison or Kelsey is where I think you should be looking,” Mike pontificated as Sophomores are prone to do,

“Uh Kelsey? No thank you. I guess I see what you mean about fat girls – I’d go for Sandra this minute even knowing she’d someday be over 200 than deal with that one!” Kevin exclaimed.

“Whoa now, Kelsey’s a strong personality but she’s not the wicked witch of the west. Just a bit of an exercise fanatic,” cautioned Michael.

“And even critical of other exercise buffs. I’ve even heard her slap at Alison, who’s trying to lean on her for support. Have you heard her once laugh or compliment anyone? She has an anger unr the hood I’d be careful of” declared Kevin.

“So then, you’re answering your own question – it isn’t just size one way or the other but the total package. And different people have both preferences and ranges of acceptance. For instance,” continued Michael, “ its fine that Kelli’s bigger but I think she needs to learn cooking basics. She know and admits it. People have done things for her all her life and she’s never really had a chance to learn. But would you believe she feels sorry for Kelsey, not angry?”

“Now you have to be kidding me – Kelli wants to mentor her roommate, who is totally the opposite?” Kevin declared

“If she knew how she might try it, yes, but I don’t think she’s thought it through that far – yet. But Kelsey hasn’t had one offer of a date from the party or even a contact , and that’s a fact. Alison and Liz, who isn’t shy about saying she’s an ex-plumper, have both had dates. And after listening here I guess we all know why.’

“Can I suggest something – if you don’t mind?” volunteered Clark, who had been discreetly quiet.

“What?” replied Kevin and Michael togerther.

Clark took a deep breath. “One of the remarks Kelsey made at the party was that she knew how to cook health food instead of the stuff we had. Say what you will about her distant superior attitude I don’t think she makes claims she can’t back up. Do you think she’d go along with teaching Kelli cooking if she thought Kelli would then help her maintain her tofu life style?”

“Hmmm,” mused Michael. “As long as I promise to make it up on weekends it might be doable.


Later on Michael invited Kelli out to a Greek gyro café for a couple of wraps and some baklava. He knew it would be her supper but his real goal was to discuss Clark’s suggestion.

“You know it might actually work. I’ve come to be proud of my body but I can see the look on Kelsey’s face whenever I’m lying ion my bed with M&M’s or a bagel. She thinks I’m a cow. But if she thought she was helping me by learning to cook her way ‘cause then I’d eat that way all the time she might do it But please don’t ask me to really go that route! My belly would protest!”

Michael nodded. He realized Kelli thought he was in the same FA camp as Mark, Robert and Jim, but didn’t care. He knew that she would acquire skills that would be adaptable to any cuisine down the road. But would Kelsey go along?

Eric meanwhile was pondering what Michael had said. He hadn’t asked either Alison or Liz out, Alison because of her interest in physical exercise which he didn’t really relish, Liz because his instincts were that she would likely become a plumper again. He’d seen her trying to be moderate at the party but could tell she really wanted more. Was he being too cautious? Did that really make a difference? He had her phone number – what harm could it do to take her out once?

He called Michael. “If I can get Liz to say yes, where would a nice place be to go on a double date? And would you and Kelli be willing to go?”

“I understand there’s a country and western show at the civic auditorium next Saturday night, but it probably costs $25 a head – the good news is that the student store has a limited 2:1 offer for those who’ve bought enough, and I bet we all have with our text books,” volunteered Michael.

“Tell me about it – over $200. But I can spring for $25. Should we do supper before or after?’

‘Doesn’t start until 8:00 so why not shoot for dnner at 5?” Michael answered.

Elizabeth was surprised to get his call and Eric sounded a little nervous but sincere. She felt comfortable being off campus with Mike and Kelli along and accepted. None of the four had any idea of the firestorm about to break in the campus paper the next morning.

It was close to midnight on Tuesday. Jim and Madison smiled in satisfaction as they did the final proof for Thursday’s front page headline story in the new Proclaimer

          POSSIBLE SERIAL KILLER
FINGERED BY PU STUDENTS

Bud Ramsey, an auto mechanic, has been arraigned in connection with the alleged disappearance and presumed death of three women in the Wichita area over the past two years, authorities have confirmed.

The bodies have not been recovered. However, articles of clothing belonging to one of the presumed victims contained DNA matching that of Ramsey, who cannot establish any reasonable other connection with the presumptive victim. Neither can he account for his whereabouts at the time of her disappearance, accord to the eight count indictment.

What is known is that a man matching Ramsey’s description approaching women in the general area and time frame has been documented in all three cases. Until two weeks ago, however, authorities did not have a name to match to the MO and description.

The break in the case came from cooperation with the Powers University Security Department. Two Powers university female students were approached by Ramsey in the last month. A third male student was close enough to one incident to make a positive ID. Ramsey in talking with one of the students had supplied his name and place of employment but she still denied his offer to join him for a date.

It was the second approach incident, leading to a verbal exchange in the Powers ding hall, that was referred to campus authorities by dining hall workers. Ramsey verbally denigrated the Reubenesque friends of the co-ed and inferred that he would be a better choice. This incensed the boyfriend of one of the students involved who tried to intervene, causing Ramsey to leave.

All three students plus two dining hall workers subsequently participated in police lineups and positively identified Ramsey, according to the indictment. What is remarkable, Proclaimer researchers have discovered, is that all police jurisdictions involved had the similarity of approach in their separate case files. However, none were concurrently aware of the others.

“Such territorial barriers exist and need to come down” insists Criminologist Gary Beckstrom. “Criminals have no restraints of city boundaries and it will only facilitate apprehensions if jurisdictions can share ongoing investigations.”

“We would like to share more, “ concurs police PR representative Julie Mitchell. “However, there are budgetary constraints and privacy concerns we have to respect. Sharing can be and is done on a selective basis, but its not feasible to do it routinely on a large scale.

Proclaimer investigative journalists have been unable to corroborate the validity of Beckstrom and Mitchell’s statements at press time, but we feel that our student body should be proud of the contribution of our classmates. Hopefully the appropriate legislative agencies will investigate this matter further.”[/indent]

“That article plus the piece on the soccer coach should stir things up,” Jim commented. “I think the DQ is open for another hour – want to drop over?”

“You know my answer yo that,” Madison said, caressing her ample belly.

Jim smiled. Madison wasn’t gaining like last year but she wasn’t getting any smaller ether. He would have been even more amazed if he’d been privy to what was going on with Kelli and Kelsey.

Kelli, whose idea of cooking was popping pizzas into a microwave, had been annoying Kelsey no end just be being her newly self-indulgent self. She still thought of her size relative to Madison and Cassie, which meant thsat ven ho she as erring a tight size16 she wasn’t actually fat fat. Kelsey of course saw her roommates 180 pound frame as an obese whale.

That night Kelli had supper in the dining hall with Michael. Nothing huge – chicken fried steak, mashed potatoes, salad and a big dessert. Of course she fully intended to have a cream cheese bagel and maybe something else at home. But she’d promised Michael to try to make nice with Kelsey be becoming her culinary student.

With that in mind she was happy to find a weary Kelsey watching television with a bottle of Gatorade. Kelli announced that she was going to the kitchen and asked Kelsey if she wanted a bagel. Kelsey, as always, declined. Then, instead of exiting to her room as she usually did, Kelli came back with her bagel plus two sodas and a large bag of chips, which she offered to share with Kelsey, who again declined.

For the next twenty minutes Kelli proceeded to polish off her bagel, both sodas and a good portion of her chips until Kelsey could take it no longer.

“How can you stand it.” she burst out finally

“Shtand Whaat?” sked Kelly innocently with her mouth full of chips.

“Packing your pie hole like that. How big a house do you want to become?” fumed Kelsey.

“Michael likes meat on my bones and I’m quite comfortable with it myself” replied Kelli, who actually had reservations she wouldn’t share. “And besides, I can’t cook that heath food you use so this is what I’m stuck with. You wouldn’t want to teach me how to do things differently would you?”

Kelsey was taken aback. Was the next campus blimp asking her for advice.? It was the first time in memory Kelsey could recall being asked to be supportive of anything.

“Well, cooking might be involved but it needs to start with menu planning. If I do it will you co-operate?” Kelsey demanded.

“Whatever you say. I’ll even help pay for the food for the first three months. Michael really wants me to master cooking and I have no idea. We always had someone to do those kinds of things:” whined Kelli.

Kelsey thought “Hmmm – if I play this right she’ll be like my servant and not have a clue.”
“OK,” agreed Kelsey. “We can start tomorrow - but I expect your full cooperation. No junk food on the premises after you use up what you have. Agreed?”

“Agreed.” said Kelli. She thought she could get a fix from Michael whenever needed. She had no idea that Kelsey was about to become a local minor celebrity when the Proclaimer came out in two days.

Madison had been working on the first story of the new semester for a while now, and she was just getting ready to submit it. She knew that this one was going to be a bomb dropped on the athletic department. This was her first story that she had done that ventured outside of the social columns which had garnered her a lot of praise. In fact, although the Proclaimer had done some really good stories over a decade ago, as Madison found in the paper's archives, for the past 10 years, it seems as if they had missed on a lot of things. Preferring to do really shallow editorials, lacking depth and just parroting national talking points that the writers had picked up to cement their already entrenched beliefs. Madison wanted to change that, she wanted to look into things that were happening on campus more deeply, and really pick up on stories that were not being covered anywhere else.

This started with the athletic department. In her opinion, it was a question that needed to be asked as to why the soccer team did not have a walk on policy. It surely was not for a depth of talent. Powers was good at some sports, but soccer was not one of them. Madison did some research on it, but came up empty in terms of actual rules prohibiting it, and the team wasn't near any kind of cap on available players. While she was writing it, she wondered what affect this would have on Kelsey. What if this backfired? Madison was all for this idea, but she didn't expect the campus to go nuts over a story about women's soccer. "If only she played basketball," Madison joked to herself, "then this would be a bigger deal." Still, Madison knew that the athletic department needed to realize what was going on, and if this was the only way to do it, then, well, so be it.

She worked pretty hard on the story, and she was spending a lot of meals grabbing more fast food than she normally had, and less home cooked meals with Jim, who understood given his prior role at the paper. However, this meant that Madison put on a bit more weight than she had before, bringing her up past 215 pounds. Most of it was contained in Madison's enlarged behind, but her thighs also looked enlarged as well, and she could swear that her shirts sleeves were a bit tighter in her upper arms. This wasn't the same crisis that it was for her last year, but nonetheless, she was hoping the weight would stop soon.

Later that week, Madison posted the story, and she left the questions up to the readers.

"Walk on policy a loser." Madison thought the title could have used work, but what the heck, it's not like she was a copywriter.

"Powers soccer team is rebulding after last year's 2-10 disaster and we have a new coach. In farness its way too esrly to second-guess him on most things. However this writer and the Proclaimer are puzzled by one bit of trivia - and possibly Powers University soccer fans will be too.:

"Why is a policy in place, new this year, excluding from tryouts potential walk-on players? Especially when this singularly impacts a potential player with a proven high school record? One who came here sincerely hoping to be a part of the program at Powers? And who has alresdy, according to our information, now been offered a slot next year at another school?

"A request to inteview our new coach about the newly modified walk-on policy was not responded to after two days.

"This writer has never met the player in question, has never seen her play, has no idea if she'd totally bomb out if given an opportunity. Our new coach may already be so loaded to the gills with potential world cup class talent that he's had to holler "no mas, por favor." But, seeing thst 80% of the team are veterans of last year's disaster, I for one doubt it.

"Come in coach - loosen up! What harm can come from at least giving the new gal a chance to compete!"

The article was being talked about around campus, and Madison liked the new attention that it was getting. The next morning, at the Proclaimer office, she wrote an email to the coach, hoping for a response from the article, but still, nothing. "Hmm, you think she would be more apt to respond after some of the PR," Madison wondered.

Alison continued her occasional workouts, with or without the help of Kelsey when available. She was determined to stay in shape, and had a front row seat to what happened if you stopped paying attention, in Madison and her friends. However, even with the desire to stay thin, occasional lapses were bound to happen, such as the one she had after her date with Kevin a few days back, where she got back to her room and had a rather large slice of cherry cheesecake after a decent sized dinner, or the more frequent ice cream after dinner. However, she told herself these things were okay, she worked out, right?

Even though she would never admit it, part of the desire to stay thin was a point of pride, she had been thin in high school, so she wanted that status to continue in college. The other part was athletics, which she greatly enjoyed. Her now recreational tennis habit, after a pretty good run in high school, was something that she wanted to keep at, and she knew that she looked pretty hot when she was out there in her informal uniform. She knew that Kevin had mentioned that he played tennis as well from their date, so she texted him, and decided, "hey, if I look hot, and I could smoke him in a match, why have I not done this yet?" So she jumped on the phone,

Hey Kev--tennis this afternoon? Can meet at the courts. Want to see game you have been tlking up.

Kevin received this text and got excited. Another chance to hang out with Alison was something that he would happily accept. However, as he looked around his dorm, he realized that he left his racquet back home. "Rats...okay...who would have one?" he thought. Kevin walked over to Clark's room, figuring maybe he by some chance had one and had just never mentioned it. "Hey Clark, you got a tennis racquet I can borrow?"

"As a matter of fact, I do." Clark's was an older one that he hadn't used for a while. He actually starred at it while he was unpacking a while back, and wondered why he had even brought it to Powers. He went into his closet and pulled it out, "Playing with Alison?" he remarked.

"Yeah, what gave me away?"

"Eh, why else would you play?"

Kevin almost chuckled at the by product his conversation with his friends, before he said goodbye to Clark and headed out. Kevin just wore some standard athletic shorts and a t, and walked over to the courts. When he got over, he saw Alison in what he assumed was her workout gear. She was wearing pink tennis shoes, an expensive brand, somewhat out of his image of her. He looked up her lean legs and thighs, towards the tight green (her high school colors) short shorts she was wearing. She also had a high school practice shirt on, which was tight and showed just a hint of her toned midsection, along with a little logo of her high school mascot, The Norse (something Kevin wanted to playfully make fun of her for). Her racquet was a nice brand, and although she was just casually checking her phone, Kevin wondered if he was even a bit intimidated by someone who clearly had some experience in this.

"Hey, you ready?" Alison said as she casually put her phone into a gym bag.

"Ok, let's see what you have." Kevin replied.

Alison wasn't about to hold back just because she liked Kevin, she had never slouched off before in the sport, so why start now? She served and although she felt rusty from her high school varsity days, it was more than enough to make a novice like Kevin fumble while trying to return. As the ball hit his racquet and flew backwards into the backstop, she realized just how much of an upper hand she had. "Oh, poor Kev, he is about to get killed," she thought.

The rest of the match didn't differ much. A Kevin had a few flukes, or balls she decided were not worth charging the net for, given the huge lead she would open up. But by the end, she had won straight sets without much of an effort.

"Wow," said a gassed Kevin, "I had no idea you were this good." After the last point wiffed past him.

"Yeah, I had some good coaching growing up."

Kevin was covered in sweat, but he was surprised to see her breaking some as well, given the effortless win she exerted on him. She had a bit of sweat on her back, and over her hairline. He wondered if that would have happened prior to coming to Powers.

"Well I lost, how about I treat us to smoothies at the Union?"

"Sounds like a deal."

They went over to the smoothie stand in the student union, which was a bit of a walk from the courts. Alison felt this to be a pretty safe option, given the healthy reputation that smoothies hold. However, what she didn't realize, was the sugar in these ones. The large strawberry kiwi one that she ordered, actually put away about 850 calories. Kevin had read an article about how some smoothies were in a sneaky way loaded with sugar and calories, but what was he going to say to her? Hey, btw, you're ordering too much? No. Plus, it's not like he didn't still have curious thoughts about that.

It was 5:00 Saturday at La Chinita restaurant on Broadway in Wichita. Michael, Kelli, Eric and Liz were ready to double date and take advantage of two student discounts: a restaurant deal thru restaurant.com and the 2:1 concert tickets from the Powers student center. Michael had become somewhat of a culinary and performing arts wizard squiring Kelli about and Eric was impressed. He expected that the total evening would cost each couple less than $50.

As they considered the modest but authentic menu a costumed waitress furnished them with two baskets of complimentary homemade tortilla chips with salsa. Michael declared his preference for the double chile rellano dinner while Kelli went with the #1 combo, which includes a corn beef taco, bean tostada and a cheese enchilada.

Eric held back, wondering what Liz would do. He knew she was a former plumper and he was curious to see how disciplined she was now. At the same time he was wrestling with his own conscience for even caring. Liz for her part was in turn was looking for Eric’s lead. It was a contest to which Michsael and Kelli were oblivious.

“Do you think I should have a pair of sanchos or the carne asada?” Liz asked Eric, who hadn’t a clue as to what either one was.

“Sanchos are tortilla with beef, beans, cheese and lettuce rolled up – sort of a fancy burrito” Michael explained. “Carne asada is a flank steak entrée with pico del gallo sauce and is usually served with rice and beans.”

“Oh,” Eric replied, totally flummoxed by Michael’s knowledge. Liz obviously knew Mexican food better than he did and Eric felt like an ignoramus. “Why don’t we order one of each and both share?”

“Sounds great to me,” replied Liz, who was starved after deliberately skipping lunch and actually eager to try some of both.

While they were waiting for their orders to arrive Liz asked Kelli how Kelsey felt about the Proclaimer article about the bullheaded soccer coaching policy.

“She’s expecting some sort of reaction from the coach and figures there’s nothing to lose, but so far nothing.” Kelli informed her. “But she did get a call from the local paper’s sports writer asking about her soccer qualifications. Now that this things been opened I don’t think its going away. But she told the reporter that she wasn’t planning to push the issue.”

“No need to. The alumni will create enough of a ruckus I think,” declared Michael.

“Yes, but after yesterday and today’s breakfast training I can tell you she’s a disciplinarian. If she gets a chance she’ll give it 110%,” Kellli observed.

“Oh yes,” replied Michael “She’s starting to teach you cooking, right?”

“Yes, and it isn’t what I feared. Actually the first meal was great – an omelet made up of two eggs, smoked salmon, asparagus and goat cheese. BUT here’s the weird thing. Once we laid out the ingredients she put us thru an exercise with barbells and leg raises. Hers weighed ten pounds and she treated them like they had the weight of napkins. i struggled to do ten with a five pound set.

“Sounds she’s in condition,” observed Eric with a tone of awe in his voice..

“Well, she’s an exercise freak who wants to be an athlete – but yeah. I don’t mind being heavier but it was a little humiliating. Then she surprised me by saying she wasn’t doing the calisthenics because of either of our weights, but to help me want to cook and eat right. Its all part of her zen, whatever that means.” Kelli shared

“And so what happened the second morning? “ asked Liz.

“Orient express oatmeal – that’s made with blueberries , with multi-grain waffles with more berries. She says that’s for anti-oxidents. I don’t know about that but it was delicious.” Kelli acknowledged. .

“And so you think you could cook these now?” asked Michsael.

“Probably, but not as fast or as organized as her.” Kelli grimaced. ”She says she expects me to do this regularly once I get the hang of it and she’ll help pay for most of the food – she realizes good ingredients aren’t cheap and wants to get away from the stuff in the dining hall. She claims I’ll eventually lose my taste for bagels if we get rid of gluten and white sugar at the start of the day and replace them with protein and anti-oxidants. But at least she’s communicating – which is the good thing. We may even get to like each other.”

“I bet she only had one waffle but you had more,” observed Liz. .

“Actually we each had two, but you’re right. I usually eat more than she lets herself. But that isn’t what this is about. I’m actually learning my way round he kitchen while getting her to loosen up on comments about my size,” gushed Kelli.

“You’re with Michael – what’s that to her?” commented Eric

“Well, I used to be smaller than now and I looked down on bigger people. I’m still not really fat but I see things different after having gained some. She’s just in a different world. Maybe by June we’ll better understand one another’s reality.”

“Well, its definitely healthy cooking,” Liz agreed. “better than the tofu and cottage cheese I would have feared for sure.

“Yes, she says you need to know what you’re cooking and be careful not to lose nutrients – stuff like licopane in tomatoes and stuff in avocados that is good for your heart. She has a version of egg mcmuffin using lean turkey, tomato and avocado that we’re doing Monday that she swears is both better and more healthy than McDonalds,” cooed Kelli with anticipation. “I know that even I can cook a muffin in the toaster, peal an avocado and slice a tomato!”

“I say congratulations and I want a breakfast invitation as soon as you’re ready,” Michael chimed in.

At this point the food arrived and the two couples spent the next half hour devouring it. Eric deliberately held back to see what Liz would do and she chattered amiably, then wound up eating over half of their shared meals, confirming his suspicion that the former plumper would likely regain herr lost pounds. . But he enjoyed their conversation and was surprised at the comfortableness Kelli and Michael had with the newly minted BBW’s size.


Around 7:00 they drove over to the two hour country and western concert. Michael and Eric waited in line at the pickup window while the girls sat on a bench, Kelli being noticeably the larger of the two. Ric remarked that it sounded like Kelli was getting an education.

“Its been a year of changing paradigms for both of us,” Michael acknowledged. “She used to rag on bigger girls and now she’s become one- but she’s nicer for it, even though I don’t know if she yet realizes how big she really is.”

“You don’t seem to mind,” Eric noted.

“Nope, not at all. She happier and better this way and I love her,” he declared.

After the concert Michael suggested hitting the local DQ and the others went along. Eric had a Blyzard along with his three companions, quietly thinking to himself that maybe he needed to reevaluate his biases.

Sandy finished the last class of her day, giving her books to Robert and promising to meet her after the meeting that she’d reluctantly agreed to. He watched as his girlfriend walked towards the Powers University administration building. She was attired in black slacks with a loose fitting Liz Claiborne button front tank top. They’d both been picked up the day before at J C Penny. Beneath the sheer snake print pattern e knew there lay a stretchy camisole that insured a modest appearance to the scoopneck top.

The objective, Robert knew, was to minimize Sandy’s food baby belly in the upcoming meeting. Over the last few weeks it had stopped receding a few hours past a meal. Instead it had simply become an ever present bulge in Sandy’s gradually expanding belly. This was due to her constant feeding of the food baby every 3-4 hours. For her and Robert this was not a problem, but in light of the Bud Ramsey situation it had landed her a referral to the school psychologist after a deposition by Ramsey’s counsel.

Sandy disappeared into the building and took the elevator to the third floor. She walked down the corridor to room A-312 and noted the sign, Dr. Janelle Farnsworth. Inhaling deeply she knocked and was greeted by a cordial “come on in – its open.”

Sitting behind the desk was a pleasant looking brunette with glasses. Sandy estimated her to be in her mid-forties.

“You re Sandra, I presume? Be seated,” the brunette psychologist offered.

Sandra complied, feeling like she was under a microscope, although Dr. Farnsworth hadn’t said or done anything hostile.

“You know you’ve been referred to me because of the Ramsey matter,” Dr Farnsworth began, coming to the point swiftly. “I’ve read the papers I can imagine its been more than a little stressful.”

“Yes, especially with the media pestering me for interviews that the police and district attorney have told me not to give. But I’m handling it. My social life and grades are both fine. I honestly don’t really know why I’m up here. I’m aware that I just have to be patient until the trial.” Sandra declared.

“And that’s it?” Dr Farnsworth pressed.

“Well, the deposition from the defense took a whole day and was a nightmare. My stress level went through the roof for a few days after that one. But I got past it,” Sandra admitted a little defensively.

“And what did you do to get past it?” came he next question.

“What I’ve always done. Find something to eat and enjoy that rather than dwelling on what’s done and can’t be changed. And, yes, I know that’s why I’m probably up here,” retorted Sandra. “Some people have made remarks that I’ve been scarfing food like it was on a sale that ends tomorrow,”

“Yes, some seem to feel the stress has increased your appetite and it might be affecting you in other ways,” concurred Dr. Farnsworth with a smile. At least this student wasn’t trying to hide anything..

“Well, yes, I have probably been eating a little more than normal to keep from focusing on all the chaos. But it hasn’t caused me to gain enough to be worried about. Actually its been rather enjoyable to eat a little more and my boy friends cool with it.” Sandra replied.

“Could I ask how much you’ve gained?” the doctor inquired.

“I don’t know and really don’t care to find out because then I might feel I had to do something about it, which frankly I’m not interested in right now. I just wish the pound police would mind their own business instead of turning me in to you..” Sandy declared.

“Well, you must realize that eating disorders can and do occur, and the authorities plus a lot of parents expect us to be vigilant. May I ask what did you had for breakfast this morning?” asked Ms, Farnsworth

“Waffles with strawberries and scrambled eggs and hash browns in the Powers University dining hall as I recall,” answered Sandy truthfully but leaving out how many and how much. It had been three waffles and a double scoop of the other two items – definitely a larger than average portion. “And, before you ask, a quesadilla for lunch along with a piece of coconut cream pie. I don’t pretend to be on a low calorie diet.”

“And in the evening?” Pressed Dr. Farnsworth.

“My meal plan only allows two dining hall meals so I eat with my roommate or go out – usually once or twice with my boy friend and on Thursdays the girls on our floor have been ordering in pizza.”

“What about afternoon and evening snacks – ever take time for those?” inquired Dr Farnsworth.

“Sometimes. I don’t keep a diary. But doesn’t everyone?” Sandy shot back, knowing full well hat for her both happened nearly every day.

“Some do, not everyone. But its how much and often that adds up,” the Dr. acknowledged. “How many calories a day do you think you are ingesting?”
.
“Probably more than the average – but I exercise and burn a lot. But yes, I know I’ve added few pounds. Shouldn’t that be my affair?” demanded Sandra,

“Well, you are over eighteen and an adult. And I’m not saying you can’t eat and weigh whatever what you choose. But if you wish we could offer help …”

“Like shots or pills or something? No thanks. If I think I’m getting too big I’ll trying working it out on my own. For now I’d just appreciate your telling the busybodies to stop wasting your time trying to run my life. As I said, I’m totally enjoying being a little fleshier and eating whatever I want. Now, is there anything else?” Sandy demanded.

“I guess not,” Dr Farnsworth sighed. “You can go and I’ll certify that you are healthy and aware of your own life situation.”

“Thank you, I’d appreciate that” said Sandy as she got up to leave. Dr Farnsworth noticed that through the newly purchased slacks the freshman’s thighs were touching and that Sandy had to subconsciously adjust her waistband as she arose. This was obviously a co-ed gaining weight but not one who needed or wanted her help.

"I've seen the pattern before," thought Dr. Fsarnsworth. "They are destined to become what they will be if they don't want help now. I just hope it works out for her, Maybe after the trial she'll have a different view, but I doubt it."
Sandy left the building thinking about what she hadn’t told Dr Farnsworth, but suspected rhe good doctor knew. She was ingesting around 4000 calories a day, twice as many as normally required for someone of her age an height, but only burning off 1000 extra. This meant that she was probably gaining two pounds a week, but really didn’t care.

She met Robert waiting in her car and gave him a smile.

“OK, let’s find a fast food place with some good burritos and I’ll tell you what happened” she said.

Kevin just sat down for lunch after a typical slate of morning classes. He was liking them more than high school, the more independent nature of a college course, with less busy work, and more individual emphasis on studying fit him well. For some students, it could have led to lower grades, but for a self starter like Kevin, the extra time spent studying, and not doing things like worksheets for a participation grade, was something he favored. If he knew it was building to something useful, he was fine putting in the effort. If it was busy work that wasn't going to lead anywhere, than it annoyed him. At the moment, Kevin was early to lunch, alone for the moment, and wondering which category his relationship with Alison fell into. Something meaningful, or busywork?

Sure, they had gone on two "dates" but had either really addressed it like that? The first one was a group dinner, and the second was a game of tennis, where he wondered if he had embarrassed himself. At that moment, Clark sat down.

"How was class?" Kevin asked Clark, who looked a bit annoyed.

"Eh, you know, same old stuff," Clark was waiting for the weekend, and this midweek lunch seemed like the furthest point from the fun of the weekend.

"Hey aren't these supposed to be our glory days?" asked a semi-joking Kevin.

"Yeah, I don't think many people look back fondly on Tuesday mornings of mid-week, regardless of the point in their life."

"Touche."

They got to talking about other things, and the conversation shifted towards Kevin's game of Tennis,

"Hey, how did that Tennis game go?" Clark asked.

"Ehh, let's be thankful that it never got on tape."

"Yikes, did my racquet survive?"

"Yes. There were no rage incidents or racquet throws, but Alison smoked me."

Clark took this as a chance to see how things were going with that, "So what is the status of you and Alison?"

"Well I think we're progressing. Neither of us have really gotten anywhere near romantic...just kind of feeling it out I guess." With that Clark raised his eyebrows and started to smile, Kevin realized the bad wording, "Ok," he stated, "figuratively feeling it out, not...yeah, ok." Luckily, that awkward moment was broken up by Eric, who was sitting down with his lunch. Eric pleasantly greeted them, and Kevin got to asking about Clark's life, "So, how do the prospects look?" Clark knew what he was reffing to, "I don't know, I may just play the field, although I think Kelsey is really hot, I just need an in with her, to see how it goes."

Although it never came up, him and Liz were also in kind of the same area as Alison and Kevin, maybe a bit further. Eric seemed absentminded during the lunch, as he had been for a few days after his date with Liz. He was trying to figure out what he would think if she pilled on some of the weight she had lost. She knew that Liz did it in part because of her critical mother's influence, so he wondered if there was something deeper there.

Speaking of Liz, she had continued to indulge. Unlike Alison and Kelsey, and even Madison, who were often in a hurry and skipped breakfast, Liz was always sure to go to the dinning hall and grab some bacon for breakfast. It was another vice that was coming out during her first semester at Powers, combined with the rest of the food she was eating, it was only a matter of time before she started to see some effects.

1531122111211211112111222222112.content:
Powers University President Michael Harrison smiled as he escorted Powers Alumni Association President Rebecca Thornburg into his office. Athletic Department Chair James A Fredericks stood as she entered. President Harrison gestured for them to both be seated, then sat down himself and took a deep breath.

“Well, we’ve all read the Proclaimer article last week – and the follow-up editorial asking why the Athletic Department isn’t willing to respond plus a listing of this Kelsey girl’s high school records. Ms Thornburg has advised me that she shares their interest. Jim, is it true that you’ve refused to be interviewed?” he asked.

“There’s nothing to be interviewed about in Coach Woolsey’s opinion. He did change the policy as claimed and intends to keep it. This Kelsey girl was unfortunately caught in the transition but we can’t let the school paper dictate school policy” Chairman Fredericks asserted.

“Even if it’s a bad policy and a losing team misses out on a possible plsayer who could help them?” queried Rebecca. “Maybe she’ll turn out to be a total no talent, but her high school record indicates this is not the case. My concern is the lack of opportunity to prove one’s self one way or the other.”

Dean Harrison realized that he needed to clarify things regarding the Proclaimer . “Professor Hastings runs the Journalism Department and he is encouraging the student staff to be more pro-active. I’ve told him that he has the Board's and my full support as long as they stick to facts. Have they been inaccurate Jim?”

Chairman Fredericks squirmed. “No – they appear to have dug up this Kelsey’s genuine high school records. Under the old rules she definitely would have been a leading contender. ”

Dean Harrison furrowed his brow. “So they do have a point that you need to deal with – stonewalling isn’t going to work. Didn’t I hear something about Janice Anderson getting injured?”

“Yes, but she’lll be back within a month.” Chairman Frdericks replied. He wanted to support his soccer coach but he knew the policy shift had been sudden and personally regretted its impact

“Still, who’s replacing her? Isn’t the team going to be one person short during training?” President Harrison pressed.

“You’re saying give her an opportunity to strut her stuff during training without calling it a walk-on?” asked Dr. Fredericks.

“No guarantees, but an opportunity Would you find that a suitable compromise, Rebecca,” President Harrison looked at the Alumni Association president her hopefully.

“It is certainly better than nothing – and you can be sure we’ll be monitoring the results,” she replied. Rebecca Thornburg was tough but also realistic.

“Good. Now Michael you can call the Proclaimer with a statement. I suggest you get it in soon for this Thursday’s issue,” intoned President Harrison with a look that said he considered that his suggestion would quickly become an accomplished fact. He had other business pending with the Alumni and this issue needed to be put to rest.

* * *

Later that day Alison saw Kelsey in the gym and immediately greeted her, “Hey Kel, what about the great news?”

“What news?” asked Kelsey, who was totally clueless as to what Alison could be referring to.

“ You haven’t heard?” Alison gushed barely taking a breath. “Madison got a call from the Athletic Department. They’ve issued a statement that you’re going to be part of the preseason training team since someone got hurt and that your long term involvement will be decided at a future date. Its going to be published in Thursday’s Proclaimer.”

Kelsey was taken by surprise. She’d spent the morning teaching Kelli how to make mock mashed potatoes using chopped cauliflower, then gone to classes. She hadn’t been near the gym.

“Wow. I guess I’d better check into this,” she reacted with her mind swirling.

Kelsey turned on her cell phone and found she had four messages. The first confirmed that the report was true. Her first practice would be at 4:00 the next afternoon, then three times a week thereafter for five weeks, assuming she was agreeable. With related conditioning exercises she quickly realized this was going to take serious free time from her schedule but she had no intention of declining.

After acknowledging the message Kelsey dashed back to her dorm apartment, hoping to catch Kelli in, which she was. She shared the good news with Kelli and asked if she could not only do the cooking but also some of the other chores - for suitable payment of course.

Kelli had been bonding with Kelsey over the last week as her understudy and decided to go along. It never hurt to be indispensible to someone. Relieved, Kelsey went off to work out. Kelli, knowing there was already a healthful green bean and mushroom casserole in the refrigerator for her and Kelsey later that night, called Michael and the two of them went out for a quick sundae.

Returning to his own dorm Michael ran into Clark and shared the news with him. Clark was both surprised and ecstatic.

“Maybe Kelsey will be willing to celebrate,” he thought. “This could be my chance to go out with her.

Aloud he simply said to Kelli’s boyfriend, “I’m happy to hear that. Do you think maybe we could make it a foursome for Saturday with Kelsey and Kelli?”

“Probably. But you should know that Kelsey’s a bit of a health nut, so don’t be surprised if she just has salad,” Michael replied. Clark shrugged, indicating that didn’t matter to him.

Michael knew what to do. First he went to Kelli and Kelsey’s apartment and announced that he and Clark wanted to celebrate her opportunity with a dinner. He asked Kelsey if she’d accept an invitation. Kelsey, who hadn’t yet been out on a date at Powers, didn’t want to offend so agreed. Later on in the evening she got a direct invitation from Clark.

Meanwhile, going to the Internet, Michael arranged for a pair of 2:1 discount coupons for an mid-scale eatery known as the Bedrock Canyon Grill. This he thought would be sure to get them out for under $30 per couple.

As they entered the grill three evenings later Clark was with Kelsey behind Michael and the full figured Kelli. Her hips seemed possibly wider than that of her escort and Clark could discern the growing collops building on the backside of her rib cage. Kelli might be trying to downplay her size but Clark knew she was fooling no one. She was obviously over fifty pounds larger than Kelsey and as big as Jessica.

He also however noticed something else. Kelli somehow exuded a confidence and vibrancy that showed. Clark had to admit that, dressed in her lime colored top and black slacks the fulsome chick looked compatible with Michael. He even had to admit that she looked good, something which in passing puzzled him.

Upon being seated they were given a courtesy order of the Grill’s famous iron skillet cornbread. Kelsey immediately sensed that she needed to be on guard but Kelli eagerly grabbed the first piece. She then began salivating as she perused the extensive menu,

“You might enjoy the Chicken Enchilada platter,” suggested Michael.

”Ummmm," cooed Kelli. “Corn tortillas filled with rotisserie chicken, topped with monterey jack and salsa verde. With sour cream and guacamole. You do know how to pick tasty items.”

“I think the Shanghai Chicken Salad might be more my style” said Kelsey, carefully avoiding any references to calories but attracting Clark’s attention anyway. “It has celery, carrots, toasted almonds, sesame seeds, mandarin oranges, and rotisserie chicken, all tossed in a spicy Asian peanut dressing and topped with crispy rice noodles. “

Clark chewed his lip thoughtfully. “This is a steakhouse, and I’m a meat and potatoes type. I think I’ll go with the ribeye. Its hand cut and hardwood‏ grilled with canyon mushrooms, then served with redskin mashed potatoes and seasonal vegetables.”

Michael grinned. “My thoughts exactly. We’ll make that two.”

Kelli reached for her second piece of corn bread while Kelsey continued to hold back while trying not to be conspicuous,

With the meal ordered Michael and Kelli began consciously plying Kelsey with questions. Clark joined in although he wasn’t in on the game, which was to help Kelsey have a great time by getting her to talk about her favorite subject – herself! In the process Clark got to know a great deal about Kelsey. Now it remained to be seen if he would ask her out on his own. The good news was that she felt comfortable with him and would likely say yes if he opportunity arose.
